Super apropriado ao momento em que vivemos... compreender o corpo humano e as histórias das pessoas que fizeram essa grandes descobertas e avanços na área da medicina é o que nos propões Bill Bryson no seu mais recente livro O Corpo - Um Guia para Ocupantes. Em janeiro quando lhe meti as mãos em cima e comecei a ler fiquei naturalmente agarrado, mas o trabalho foi tirando tempo para o completar. E eis que, de um momento para o outro, estamos fechados em casa, e tempo é coisa que não falta. Pois nada melhor que repôr os níveis de leitura que andavam em mínimos históricos. Adorei como é habitual ler e aprender com Bryson. Não desilude os fãs do género!

Бил Брайсън - "Тялото. Наръчник за употреба", изд. "Сиела" 2020, прев. Анна Карабинска-ГаневаТоку-що приключих едно невероятно пътешествие. А именно - дългото, загадъчно, удивително - и понякога стряскащо - "пътуване" из човешкото тяло."Тялото. Наръчник за употреба" в известна степен е точно това, което изглежда. Книга, в която се говори за строежа, функциите, проблемите и болестите на човешкото тяло. С /почти/ всички познати и не дотам познати термини и сложни думи, коитно някои от нас са чували, но повечето вероятно не са. И, както вероятно би казал самият автор, това понякога може да звучи объркващо, а в много случаи - откровено неразбирае��о.Не и когато за тези неща пише автор като Бил Брайсън. Неслучайно сравних четненето на тази книга с пътуване. Не само защото Брайсън действително ни превежда из всички органи и системи на човешкото тяло. А и защото при всяко пътуване, особено из /относително/ непозната територия е много важно да имаме добър водач. А Брайсън определено е такъв. Без излишно "залитане" към сложни и "твърде умни" думи, на ясен и разбираем език той ни запознава с всяка една част и важен орган от тялото. Прави го по онзи начин, който води до неусетно и лесно запомняне. Понякога - дори с невероятното си чувство за хумор./Деликатно и премерено, без да звучи непочтително./Направи ми впечатление огромната библиография, цитирана в края на книгата, както и фактът, че освен това по време на проучванията си Брайсън се консултира и с голям брой медици и други специалисти в съответните области. Можи би, четейки книгата, човек би се запитал: "Откъде този не-специалист знае всички тези неща?" или дори: "Не е ли твърде самоуверено човек, който не е свързан професионално с медицината, да пише подобна книга?" Признавам, че в някакъв момент аз се питах същото. Съмненията ми бяха разсеяни именно от библиографията и цитиланите ксонсултации със специалисти.Разбира се, всеки от нас има поне основни познания за нещата, споменати или подробно опидсани в книгата. Но лично аз научих купища интересни подробности, които може и да не ми потрябват никога - но потвърждават за пореден път това, което понякога осъзнаваме - че нашето тяло е едно истинско чудо. Една все още не съвсем разрешена загадка. Че понякога /за съжаление твърде често/ сме безкрайно небрежни към него. И че е истинско чудо как то се бори за нас и успява да ни защити /или поне предпази донякъде/ от собствената ни неразумност.Една от най-интересните глави ми беше тази, посветена на съня. Мислила съм си често нещата, които прочетох в нея. Задавала съм си същите въпроси. И също както и тук, още търся отговорите. Много интересна ми беше и главата "Нерви и болка". Тя отговори на доста от "чуденките" ми, донякъде дори по въпроса за главоболието - въпрос, който ме занимава по лични причини, откакто се помня.В "Тялото. Наръчник за употреба" Брайсън е ссъщо толкова великолепен, колкото и в другите си книги, може би дори повече, защото темата е много по-сериозна. И най-хубавото - тя не е "книга за специалисти". Смятам, че би могла да бъде разбрана достатъчно добре от всеки, който не е "проспал" часовете по биология в училище.Чаках тази книга с голямо нетърпение, и сега определено мога да кажа, че е имало защо. Ако ви се чете информативна, достъпно и интелигентно написана книга по теми, които засягат всеки един от нас - препоръчвам я с две ръце. Заслужава си.

Bill Bryson’s books are like the literary equivalent of the British panel show Qi. Like an episode of the long-running series, his books are filled with tidbits of trivia presented in a quirky and humorous way. While Bryson is often quite ambitious in tackling the subjects that interest him (attempting to explain the universe in 2003’s A Short History of Nearly Everything), no single book should be considered the definitive account on any topic.As indicated above, the disclaimer also applies to The Body. Bryson breaks down the human body and attempts to answer questions about what makes us.. us. The author tackles everything from the top of your head to the tips of your toes and everything in between. Why do we itch? Why are we filled with millions of microbes at any given time? Why are some viruses deadly and others pass through without even a sign they were there? Why on a long enough timeline, do we all eventually get cancer? These are just a few of the questions Bryson tackles in his new book.There were many moments where I audibly gasped reading this book and struggled with whether I should tell my hypochondriac partner what I read. I did read her one bit about a woman who scratched through her skull and into her brain during sleep and judging by Alaina’s scream, I hesitated to read any more unsettling parts aloud.It’s amazing the level of sophistication we have only now when it comes to surgery. Obviously, things evolve, but it is horrific to hear about the irresponsible way we even practiced lobotomies and brain surgery in the mid 1900s. No sterilization, just cram an icepick into your eye sockets and wiggle it around until you sever key components of the human brain. There’s no way we could have gotten to where we are now without having to experiment over the years, but I could think of better things to do than trying to transfuse our blood stream with beer and milk.One of the most interesting parts of the book deals with how the brain interprets the information sent by our eyes. Bryson writes that it takes one fifth of a second for what we see to be interpreted by the brain. So we are never truly seeing the present. Wild, eh? So, our brain makes up the difference by forecasting what the world will look like a fifth of a second from now. So, as Bryson says, “we are all living in a world that does not exist yet.”One thing I will say – I’m no expert in science let alone how the human body works. Maybe I have somewhat of an idea of how mine struggles to get through the day, but I couldn’t tell you if Bryson made any big errors or mistakes in this book. Luckily, there are reviews like this one who can speak more authoritatively on the matter. While the reviewer did point out a few errors, the majority of the book seems to be sound.I really enjoyed this read and definitely recommend it.. I feel like I learned a lot, or at least things that I can bring up randomly in conversations. For example, to build Benedict Cumberbatch from scratch would cost you $151,578.46. So, there’s that.

No nos digamos mentiras: leer sobre uno mismo es normalmente un verdadero placer (aunque algunos nos avergoncemos a veces). Pero más placentero aún es leer sobre la ciencia de tu propio cuerpo. Esto es lo que hace este libro maravilloso. Desbaratarte por dentro y por fuera, no dejar ninguna esquina de tu fantástico (y "sucio") cuerpo sobre la cual hablar.El libro esta increíblemente bien escrito. Tiene un lenguaje llano casi completamente exento de tecnicismos médicos y biológicos, con una dosis precisa de anécdotas, historia y datos curiosos (¡cientos de datos curiosos!). Leí el libro en inglés porque creo no esta todavía traducido (y no acostumbro hacerlo porque no soporto no saber el significado de todas las palabras de un libro o tener que estar buscando como si fuera un escolar), pero aún así, y a diferencia de muchos libros, lo encontré agradable y fácil de leer.El texto no tiene una estructura definida, cada capítulo se ocupa de un "aparte" del cuerpo humano, el sistema inmune ("el órgano más increíble"), los pulmones y la respiración, el departamento de química (hormonas y otras sustancias producidas por las múltiples glándulas del cuerpo), la comida (que no es una parte, pero sí un importante "capítulo" del funcionamiento de esta máquina maravillosa), los nervios y el dolor, etc. Esta falta de una "estructura", que sería mas propia de un libro académico, hace aún más agradable la lectura en tanto confirma lo que es el libro: un texto fácil y agradable de leer para todos.Solo le veo un defecto: después de leerlo, como sucede después de ir al médico, terminas demasiado consciente de todo lo que pasa. Ahora siento más frío que antes y se lo achaco al hecho de que ya pase de los 45 y he empezado un lento pero inevitable "decaimiento físico" que incluye perder no solo masa muscular sino la capa de grasa subcutánea que mantiene calienticos a los más "pipiolos"; ya no puedo comer sin pensar en las perniciosas grasas trans o en la comida súper procesada con la que nos envenenamos lentamente; no puedo estar sentado más de una hora sin pensar que las enfermedades más graves de la modernidad no son las enfermedades cardíacas o el Alzheimer, sino el estilo de vida y una alimentación poco saludable. En fin: ¡ahora todo me parece indicio de que algo anda mal en mi cuerpo! Pero eso me pasa a mí que soy un poco neurótico.Lean libro y comprueben por ustedes mismos.

Nuestras células y órganos poseen un funcionamiento complejo y a la vez elogiable. A medida que uno comprende más acerca de la fisiología, más dudas le surgen acerca de cómo es posible de que falle tan poco a menudo en nuestra vida diaria. Bill Bryson escribe a lo largo de más de veinte capítulos sobre los distintos sistemas del cuerpo, como el sistema digestivo o el inmunitario, y también se mete a comentar aspectos sobre nuestro sueño, la muerte o el cáncer.Es libro es innegablemente atractivo y se devora solo. Está salpicado de curiosidades sobre nuestros órganos, también de anécdotas de pacientes y médicos pioneros en el tratamiento de las enfermedades, a la vez que ofrece varios datos y estudios para soportar la argumentación. El autor mantiene un tono muy ameno - varias veces gracioso - y no se suele meter en complejidades, a la vez que parte de la humildad de lo que descubre y admira a las personas a las que entrevista durante el libro. El ansia por saber con qué te va a sorprender Bryson en la siguiente página mantiene la atención, ya que ha compuesto un volumen que es a la vez una historia de la medicina, una revisión de parámetros de salud de las últimas décadas y un inicio de tratado de fisiología. Todo bastante modesto, claro.Como aspectos para no darle la máxima puntuación, destacaría el exceso de utilizar personajes con nombres propios. No dudo de la importancia capital de todos los médicos, pacientes e investigadores a los que se hace referencia, pero basar tanto el texto en estos protagonistas aleja el verdadero objeto de estudio del libro, que no es sino nuestra anatomía y su funcionamiento. Puede que el tono dé algunos rodeos atípicos, pero es un sello del escritor. Es una obra divulgativa de la que es seguro que se pueden subrayar decenas de datos interesantes, no profundiza pero tampoco lo pretende.

I don't normally rate or review a book before I finish it, but I gotta tell people about this delightful and informative book! It is quintessential Bill Bryson, at his best, full of humor, history, and LOADS of information about the body, all kinds of things you often wondered about (like how long food stays in your stomach or your intestines) or never thought about at all, like ow many times a day you blink (14,000). The research he clearly did for the book is extremely impressive, and I'll bet it was fun.It is taking me a while to read the book, not because I do not like it but because I am enjoying it so much. I limit myself to one or two chapters daily; there is so much content that it can be overwhelming in large doses. Let me give you one caution: it might be best to read this book when you are alone, because otherwise you are going to annoy your family members, whom you will interrupt VERY frequently because you MUST share the latest fascinating and/or funny tidbit with them. Of course, you could avoid the problem by listening to the book together; that would provoke some very interesting conversation!

Ca de obicei, Bill Bryson face o treabă excelentă și sunt slabe șansele să nu fi entuziasmat de felul în care el își construiește cărțile, dacă le-ai alege, pentru că îmbină într-o manieră foarte abilă prezentarea subiectelor pe înțelesul tuturor celor care îl citesc cu erudiția și documentarea științifică.Ceea ce face și în „Corpul”, o prezentare exhaustivă și plină de referințe despre acest complex și complicat mecanism care este corpul nostru. Și o face în capitole distincte, luând la rând fiecare organ, parte sau sistem al corpului, disecându-l pentru a-l face mai ușor de înțeles și de cei care nu sunt specialiști. Și nu se oprește numai asupra acestora, ci discută și despre echilibru, boli, durere, medicină sau hrană, ca să nu mai vorbim despre... sfârșit. Cu erudiție, cum spuneam, și cu umor, așa cum ne-a obișnuit Bill Bryson. Excelent, as usual!

I think whether or not you enjoy this book depends on your current level of knowledge about the subject matter. For me there was nothing new in the is book and to some extent an over emphasis on figures such as the length of this, that and the other. There were also blatantly wrong statements. Bryson describes a cancer hospital in the Netherlands, its patients (all ventilated according to the author) scooting around on toy cars or bicycles. I feel he must be referring to naso-gastric tubes rather than ones to help you breathe. Such a mistake is unforgivable not only on the part of the author but of the editors. Readers should be able to trust the information they are given in non-fiction

I'm currently a third year medical student and I honestly wasn't expecting this book to be brief yet so informative. It talked about the body, from up to down, inside and out. The author only briefly discusses parts of the body and tends to explain medical jargons in a way that an average person could understand. His discussions mostly begin with a historical background of the disease or operation, and then he correlates it with the disease and organ involved. Everything he talked about here (as far as I can remember) is medically correct and accurate. Highly recommended even to non-medical field related people who are just interested to know everything, but not the entirety, of the human body.

I have been living in this body for 60 + years but it wasn't until I read this book did I learn about how many of it's system function and what doctors and scientists already know. Easy to read, entertaining, all the while being scientific make this a great informative book.

As with all of his other books, we, his readers, benefit from Bryson's curiosity and enthusiasm about his subjects. He manages to find fresh material and present it so clearly that I always feel as if I've been taught by a master. I also appreciate that he reads his own books in his own style.

I imagine the conversation with his publisher:Publisher: A Short History of Nearly Everything was so funny and educational. People loved it. You should write something similar about the body.Bill: I'm not interested.Publisher: Write it anyway. It will make a lot of money.Bill: OK.

Sempre piacevole leggere un libro di Bryson, anche se in questo caso lo spunto per regalarci aneddoti e dati poco conosciuti (e cioè il corpo umano, e quanto poco generalmente se ne sappia) mancava di un vero e proprio filo conduttore, facendo sì che ogni capitoli fosse a sé stante.Alla fine il libro è un elenco di nozioni e di storie relative a svariate parti del corpo, una dopo l'altra.Interessante e d'intrattenimento (questo autore è una fonte apparentemente inesauribile di aneddoti assurdi e divertenti), ma mi ha preso meno di altri suoi libri.Possibile sia stato anche a causa di un periodo in cui ho avuto poco tempo da dedicargli, ma di solito se un libro mi cattura il tempo per leggere salta fuori. Qui invece una lettura altrimenti rapida è durata quasi due settimane, qualcosa non è scattato.Comunque, mi ripeto, interessanti le nozioni e divertenti gli aneddoti.Inoltre, quanti dottori e primari e scienziati conosce Bill???E poi, la parte sul nostro essere pressoché completamente impreparati di fronte alla possibilità dell'arrivo di una pandemia, il fatto che la stessa influenza sia pericolosissima e che ogni anno venga scelto quasi per caso il ceppo per cui creare il vaccino stagionale, i raffronti con le epidemie del passato... questa parte mi ha fatto rabbrividire. Specialmente perché il libro è uscito a fine 2019, quando cominciava a girare il Covid, ancora di nascosto...Lascia a bocca aperta quanto poco si sappia del corpo e del suo funzionamento, non solo noi "utilizzatori" di un corpo ma pure gli esperti, medici e scienziati. O quante scoperte siano state frutto totalmente del caso, o di errori. O gli orrori medici del passato.Francamente non capisco perché non mi sia piaciuto di più questo libro...

Bill Bryson takes the reader on a tour of the human body. It is well-organized by type of function. It is a book of popular science, geared toward the non-scientist. It is a compilation of secondary sources, anecdotes, and historical episodes. Bryson dispels a few myths and imparts useful facts about health. This author is known for his humor, but this book is not particularly humorous. In fact, a strong stomach will be needed for a few segments. There is a good amount of repetition that probably should have been edited out. I think your reaction to it will depend on how much of this material you have already heard (or read). I read science books regularly, so I was already familiar with most of this information. It is reasonably entertaining but if you are looking for scientific analysis, there are other books I would recommend ahead of this one.
Informatii interesante, unele cunoscute, altele mai putin (ex. o multime de detalii din viata oamenilor de stiinta), date statistice, toate prezentate intr-un mod accesibil publicului larg.

You know what you are going to get from a Bryson book of this type. Quirky stories aligned to historical/modern facts about the subject at hand. The subject at hand is you. Well, your body. All of it. From top to toe and all bits in-between. From the time you were conceived to the time you die.What a great journey it is. I was boring the family by stopping them watching Saturday evening TV by telling them facts about their body that they didn’t really want to hear that I found fascinating. Do you know that 59 elements are needed to construct a human being. Carbon, oxygen, hydrogen, nitrogen, calcium and phosphorus account for 99.1%. Did you know that the formal name for skin is the cutaneous system. The inner layer is called the dermis. The outer layer is called the epidermis. Skin and hair are made largely of the same stuff – keratin. There are so many more examples of this. You can see why they wanted to lock me away in the kitchen to read and stop bothering them.The thing is with Bryson is that he knows how to weave a really complicated subject into a text that is readable, entertaining and educating. Admittedly a lot of the facts and stats he throws at you are mind-boggling. I took about 5 pages of A4 notes. It could have been a lot more but I would have ended up just copying the book.The research is, of course, extensive. He spoke to so many people and must have read a load of medical journals and books. Some of the stories on these early, mainly Victorian, medical pioneers who would experiment on themselves to see if certain techniques, drugs and even surgery would work sometimes with great effect but a lot of the time failing resulting in terrible injuries including death.What do you think the most devastating disease in history is? It infected nearly everyone that was exposed to it. It killed 30% of its victims. 500 million died.In 1872 Charles Darwin published a book on expressions and it showed that all people, whatever their race, shared a common heritage. Fear, anger, surprise, pleasure, disgust and sorrow are universal. The most universal of them all is the smile. Keep Smiling everyone.

Bill Bryson teaches you everything you didn’t know you wanted to know about the human body in this book. Bryson takes on the brain and skin and hair and the skeleton and the immune system and lungs and food and guts and sleep and birth and nerves and pain and disease and cancer and death. He tells the stories of the scientists behind the discoveries about the body. Everything is backed with science and footnotes, and that’s part of the delight in this book, but the other part are the anecdotes about the body and the people studying the body, and that’s a true joy.This is the kind of book that (probably) drives everyone else in your family crazy; you read a little and you can’t help yourself from reading parts of it aloud, and then you laugh together and walk away, and you read some more, and then you share some more, and on and on to the end. A new favorite nonfiction read.

I loved this, and I don’t really get the appeal of Bill Bryson - I always find his books kind of meh, so loving this one was a very happy surprise. Now I’ll try not to drop everything I’ve learned here into conversation as frequently as possible, but did you know that oysters can get herpes? Or that 4% of (lucky-ass) people say they’ve never gotten a headache? Or that men DON’T think about sex every seven seconds? (Why/how did we ever think they did in the first place?) This book will school you good.
Took me a while to get throught this, not because it wasn't interesting but that it could be read a little bit at a time. And I've been kinda busy this year.

The Body was written in a breezy tone, but is surprisingly substantive in its brief tour of the human body, description of modern knowledge of physiology and medicine, and its historical and often chatty vignettes of science and discovery. "Brief" is a bit of a misnomer, as The Body is about 550 pages long, but it could have easily been twice as long (and dense) in someone else's hands.I enjoyed Bill Bryson's trivia. Did you know that each of us contains about 30 trillion human cells and between 30-50 trillion bacterial cells? That between one and five of our cells turns cancerous every day – and that our immune system captures and kills (most of) them? Or that: Your lungs, smoothed out, would cover a tennis court, and the airways within them would stretch nearly from coast to coast. The length of all your blood vessels would take you two and a half times around Earth. The most remarkable part of all is your DNA (or deoxyribonucleic acid). You have a meter of it packed into every cell, and so many cells that if you formed all the DNA in your body into a single strand, it would stretch ten billion miles, to beyond Pluto. (p. 15)I enjoyed The Body, but Bryson drove me nuts as he often shared a tidbit, then moved on without following up his point. Sometimes, as when he said that teens were four times as likely to be in a car accident when they were with other teens, I knew why. (Distractedness and poorer executive functioning relative to adults.) But why tell us that the American Heart Association pushed down the criterion for hypertension from 140/90 to 130/90 if you're not going to tell us why?Bryson included many photos of scientists he discussed. I enjoyed them, but I would have appreciated and preferred line drawings of the structures described. Doing so would have made the book much more useful and user-friendly.

5 starsThis was a horrendously informative read. The author tackles the human body from top to bottom, of course the important parts or the fascinating ones. He also talks about the medical/medicine history. Every chapter had something interesting to tell, statistics on how it was before and now or how it differs from country to country or region. The baffling power of our body and mind. The myths or legends which are still haunting our society. The most cringe worthy parts were two in this book,1)The tests were done on humans with new medicines along with surgeries (thank the lord, i am not a medical person. I m a coward). 2)How so many medicines we are taking now, are still not the exact solution for the ailments.  Well researched, each chapter tells us not about a body part but also the medical history, politics involved, experiments done etc which was very interesting. Even after these many years of research oh human body and as human residing inside a body, we almost know nothing much concrete about it. Body keeps amazing us.Happy Reading!

Bill Bryson is somebody else who agrees that we overtest, overoperate and prescribe too many medications, especially here in America, but, with variations by country, throughout the modern west. Nothing earthshaking in this book for me, but just a good Bryson science popularizing romp.That said, he did have one or two things that "made me think."One was about the idea that, due to nerve transmission speed, our eyes-to-brains system "sees" things with 1/5 second delay behind reality, but that the brain does its best job of confabulating what live time reality should be. Well, with recent reports on the German background of the famous, or infamous, Libet experiment, I got to wondering if maybe, even though Libet got some things wrong, BUT other things right (biggest wrong — whatever this delay is, it doesn't disprove free will in some version and it surely doesn't prove determinism), maybe there's something kind of related here.The other thing? I never knew before — even tho it has a subhead within Wiki — that Mona Lisa has no eyebrows. And is also light on eyelashes. I know many people have commented on its "eyes follow you around the room" effect, while also noting this isn't the only painting that does that. But — does the no eyebrows/light eyelashes help the effect?Bryson is also good on the basics of pointing out how modern medicine and biology refute the idea of "race." Skin color is literally one mm deep. Beyond the commonly known blood type groups, there are many others — which could be used to reclassify what a "race" is, if one did want to go down that road.Finally, Bryson ends with "the end." It's the human body. We die. Why? Without going Kurzweil, how much can we extend the lifespan? First, even as they remain in the news? Telomeres have only a small effect on the aging process. So, ignore any supplements or other claims to boost your telomeres. Second, the causes of aging are many. Third, on causes of death? Alzheimer's continues to rise, but dozens of other dementias exist. Cancer has many, many causes, and in part because of that, no cure is around the corner.In the background, with Bryson joviality, lurks a message of acceptance.

Това е книга, която ако решиш да я четеш, трябва да си много сигурен, че си готов да живееш с информацията, която ще получиш. Книгата почва като любовно обяснение към човешкото тяло докато преминаваш през различните системи, органи и скелета. Определено помага да погледнеш към тялото си от различна гледна точка и с малко повече любов към всичките не най-приятни неща, които тялото прави понякога и да си най-вече по-добронамерен към тялото си, което определено може да мине за много изтезаван роб, визирайки на какво го подлагаме ежедневно. След любовното обяснение книгата прави U-turn и ти сервира информация, която върви ръка за ръка с осъзнаването, че медицината и фармацията не са точно това, което всички мислим, че са, и това е доста напрягаща информация да поемеш. Като всяко друго нещо в този живот - трябва да направиш проучване за себе си и да вземеш решение на база какви са твоите цели и желания за живота ти. Докторите са хора като нас и не са всесилни. Ти наемаш техните знания и заедно вземете решение, не докторът поема бремето за твоя живот, той си е твоя отговорност. Когато разберем това, може би и медицината ще бъде медицина, а не здравна индустрия, чиято единствената цел е добра печалба.Накрая книгата стига до най-мрачните и депресиращи части, където колкото и да си подготвен, някои неща просто ти идват тежички за преглъщане. Книгата трябва да се чете с отворено съзнание и ако не си готов да приемеш, че как ще умреш е въпрос на времето в което живееш, на гени и на супа от случайни обстоятелства, не я чети!!Много хора предпочитат да не знаят и да вярват, че докторите имат всички отговори и че медицината може да предложи някое вълшебно лекарство, което да излекува каквото ти има. Няма лошо, всички правим това, което помага най-много на мозъкът ни да оцелее. Другата група, която би харесала тази книга, са тези които предпочитат да знаят, за да избегнат ненужен прием на лекарства или манипулации, и дори ако са нужни - да изберат до колкото могат с ясно съзнание, че те са взели решението, не някой друг.Определено прекрасна книга. Кара те да мислиш, да разсъждаваш, да се чудиш, да поемеш отговорност, което е всичко, че и повече, от което може да очакваш от една добра книга. :)

I'm becoming increasingly convinced Bill Bryson is one of the great prose stylists of the English language. That sounds bizarre, I know, but look at this: "The skin consists of an inner layer called the dermis and an outer epidermis. The outermost surface of the epidermis, called the stratum corneum, is made up entirely of dead cells. It is an arresting thought that all that makes you lovely is deceased. Where body meets air, we are all cadavars. These outer skin cells are replaced every month. We shed skin copiously, almost carelessly; some twenty five thousand flakes a minute, over a million pieces every hour. Run a finger along a dusty shelf, and you are in large part clearing a path through fragments of your former self. Silently and remorselessly we turn to dust."This goes on for 500 pages without a single boring paragraph. Essentially, he uses every tool a writer has to supercharge information--and he's incredibly good at it. The book is often quite funny, but occasionally quite profound or even shocking. I've devoured each of his science-themed books in a few days, and it seems I won't be able to resist at least trying out the ones on language.

A great read if you enjoy wacky science trivia that starts at the skin and burrows all the way down to your heart, bones, and everything else packed inside us. We are definitely more than a bag of bones, and Bryson makes that abundantly clear. He does a comprehensive job of discussing each part of the human body, pointing out what we do and don’t know regarding physiology and medicine alongside the historical quirks of discovery. There are some nice pop culture references and silly humor scattered throughout to keep the info easy to digest. We never get too bogged down in the details, which is perhaps a curse if you want to know just a little bit more about something Bryson mentions. But hey, Google can’t hurt you there.This book will not be for those looking for detail. In fact, Bryson name-drops a few fantastic authors and experts in their fields, Siddhartha Murkerjee, Atul Gawande, Martin Blaser, and Jerome Groopman, to name a few. Their books a definitely worth checking out. Overall, The Body is definitely worth a read or two, so please go on ahead and dip your toes into it!

Bryson has a great ability to explain complicated issues and provide funky facts so his tomes on how everything works in the universe, home and now in this one, on the body tend to be worthwhile reads. I got hooked on his writings with "A Walk in the Woods" where he attempts the Appalachian trail with a high school friend after living abroad for many years and have found his travel books about Britain, the U.S. and Australia to be very entertaining. And I guess that is why if one expects a similar level of mirth in his educational material one is likely to be disappointed. However, if some education is what you are seeking, this book will serve you well.

Very interesting, and also terrifying in several spots (you don't want to know the surgery procedure for bladder stones and for mastectomies in the 17th-18th centuries, sweet merciful Asclepeius you do NOT want to know). Also moderately terrifying is how often Bryson and the many doctors and scientists he consulted for this book admit that this organ/procedure/portion of the brain does X...but we don't know how, or why. Honestly, the book could be alternately titled "The Body: How the F*** Does It Work?"

Another beaut Bryson book. His usual attention to detail, little known events, plenty of facts, quirky characters and his quota of Dad jokes. It's an impressive coverage of the human body, what makes us tick and what doesn't. He highlights how much we do not know, that lifestyle has more to do with your health than medical science, that many advances were quite accidental and scientists seem to hate each other. A good book to have as a reference.

I'm well-versed in anatomy and physiology, having been a nurse for more decades than I care to admit. I wasn't sure there would be much new information in this book. Boy, was I wrong!Interesting details about every body system; information that has been gleaned from research and factual sources.I enjoyed the audio version of The Body: A Guide for Occupants, with the author being the narrator. I'm guessing the book is just as interesting.

Finished this book while I was recuperating from sickness during this pandemic and it did trouble me somehow that despite the body marvelously always wanting to subsist it happens that it sabotages itself. The accounts of experimentation done by humans to come to today's still young understanding were amusing, most times shocking, other times squeamish. I will always be awestruck by how our body is made up of endless mysteries. I guess all that we are ever here for is to wonder.

WOW, I am amazed at how much I did NOT know about the human body! Mr Bryson made this interesting, informative and fun.My thanks to Netgalley and Doubleday Books for this advanced readers copy. This book is due to release in October 2019.

I wasn't big on the sciences in school, but Bill Bryson has written a book that keeps me turning pages and taking notes to talk about with everyone! Parts may make you squeamish, but 2 paragraphs later you will be laughing out loud! I see this as Christmas gifts this year! Enjoy!

Eight, nine, ten stars! I read a tiny bit of this book while I was still living in Colorado, picked it up again last week and read right through 386 pages. Bryson is an amazing writer and every page of this book was fascinating. You can probably tell that he’s my favorite author.

From the first paragraph, to the last page, it was a non-stop delight. The way it was written makes anyone feel like they are on a curious journey through a world we thought we knew, but have no idea! A book I would read more than once!
Bryson delves into the human and reveals so many fascinating and little-known facts and scientific historical discoveries, delivered in his engaging style as always

¡Terminado! Bueno y detallado, pero no a la altura de lo que me habían dicho, encontré yo. Quizá sea que leo demasiados libros de ciencia, jajaja, entonces la competencia es ardua, pero para gente que haya explorado menos, es un buen punto de inicio, porque es detallado y meticuloso sin ser latero. De hecho, en ocasiones hasta me hizo reír, con carcadas y todo. Mucho humor británico el señor, aunque sea originario de los Estados Unidos se nota que ha pasado más de la mitad de su vida allí.Cuatro estrellas porque igual es súper bueno. Hay partes en que la información que dio estaba un tanto desactualizada, pero aún así creo que vale la pena leerlo, en especial si se ha indagado poco en lo absolutamente maravillosa que es la naturaleza.Algunas citas que destaqué :D 1. Awww, y sí.Con frecuencia se compara al cuerpo con una máquina, pero en realidad es mucho más que eso: trabaja las veinticuatro horas del día durante décadas sin necesidad (en su mayor parte) de un mantenimiento regular o la instalación de piezas de repuesto; funciona con agua y unos cuantos compuestos orgánicos; es suave y bastante bonito; resulta convenientemente móvil y flexible; se reproduce con entusiasmo; cuenta chistes, siente afecto y sabe apreciar una encendida puesta de sol y una refrescante brisa. ¿Cuántas máquinas conoce que sean capaces de hacer algo de eso? No hay ninguna duda: somos una auténtica maravilla. Pero hay que decir que, entonces, también lo es una lombriz de tierra.2.Aunque lo hagamos casi todo mal, nuestro cuerpo nos mantiene y preserva. La mayoría de nosotros somos testimonio de ello de una u otra forma. Cinco de cada seis fumadores no contraer cáncer de pulmón. La mayoría de las personas que integran el grupo de los principales candidatos para sufrir ataques cardiacos no sufren ataques cardiacos. Se estima que cada día entre una y cinco de nuestras células se vuelven cancerosas, pero el sistema inmunitario las captura y las mata.Piense en ello. Un par de docenas de veces a la semana, que son más de mil veces al año, contraemos la enfermedad más temida de nuestra época y, en cada una de esas ocasiones, nuestro cuerpo nos salva. Desde luego, muy de vez en cuanto un cáncer se convierte en algo más grave y puede que nos mate, pero en términos generales los cánceres son raros: la mayoría de las células del cuerpo se replican miles y miles de millones de veces sin equivocarse. Puede que el cáncer sea una causa común de mortalidad, pero no constituye un suceso común en la vida.3.Antes se creía que la despigmentación probablemente tardaba entre 10.000 y 20.000 años en producirse, pero hoy, gracias a la genómica, sabemos que puede ocurrir mucho más deprisa, probablemente en solo 2.000 o 3.000 años.* Ya lo saben, si ustedes se van a vivir a un lado tropical y su hermano a un lugar helado, en apenas dos o tres milenios serán DE OTRA RAZA. Ergo: la "raza" es tan superficial que no existe.4. Jajaja. Genial.De manera similar, hasta ahora nadie ha conseguido explicar ni de lejos por qué se nos arruga la piel de los dedos cuando nos damos un baño prolongado. La explicación más frecuente es que las arrugas les ayudan a drenar mejor el agua y facilitan el agarre, pero en realidad eso no tiene mucho sentido: sin duda, las personas que más urgentemente necesitan tener un agarre son las que acaban de caer al agua, no las que llevan ya un tiempo en ella.5.A diferencia del resto del cuerpo, las palmas de las manos no sudan en respuesta al esfuerzo físico o al calor, sino únicamente a causa del estrés. Esa sudoración emocional es la que se mide en las pruebas del polígrado (detector de mentiras).6.Alrededor del 60% de los hombres son prácticamente calvos al cumplir los cincuenta, y a uno de cada cinco le ocurre a los treinta. Poco se sabe de ese proceso, pero sí sabemos es que una hormona llamada dihidrotestosterona tiende a desbaratarse un poco con la edad, haciendo que los folículos pilosos de la cabeza se cierren y que, en cambio, los más reservados de las fosas nasales y las orejas broten desesperadamente. La única cura conocida para la calvicie es la castración* La naturaleza es malvada, jaja, pero rigurosa. Por ahí leí que los transgéneros que van de mujer a hombre, se quedan pelados si les tocaba ser pelados. En ese caso el sexo elegido termina siendo más fuerte que el original, por así decirlo.7. Una de las veces que Bryson me hizo reír.El 80% del aire que respiramos es nitrógeno. Es el elemento más abundante en la atmósfera y es vital para nuestra existencia, pero no interactúa con otros elementos. Cuando respiramos, el nitrógeno del aire penetra en los pulmones y vuelve a salir de inmediato, como un comprador distraído que ha entrado en la tienda equivocada.8.El más habitual de nuestros posibles tropiezos virales no deseados es el resfrío común. Todo el mundo sabe que si se enfría es más probable que se resfríe (al fin y al cabo, por eso lo llamamos resfriado), pero hasta ahora la ciencia no ha podido determinar por qué ocurre eso, o incluso si realmente ocurre. No cabe duda de que los resfriados son más frecuentes en invierno que en verano, pero eso podría deberse únicamente al hecho de que pasamos más tiempo en espacios interiores y, en consecuencia, estamos más expuestos a las fugas y exhalaciones microbianas de los demás.9. Por esto su servidora toma antibióticos tarde mal y nunca.Ya en 1945, en su discurso de aceptación del Premio Nobel, Fleming advirtió que los microbios podían desarrollar fácilmente resistencia a los antibióticos si estos últimos se utilizaban de manera descuidada. Raras veces un discurso del Nobel ha resultado más profético.10. Awww y jajaja.El cerebro resulta ser, con mucho, el más costoso de nuestros órganos. Sin embargo, también es maravillosamente eficiente. Nuestro cerebro requiere solamente de unas 400 calorías diarias de energía, casi lo mismo que obtenemos ingiriendo una magdalena de arándanos. Intente hacer funcionar su ordenador portátil 24 horas con una magdalena y verá el resultado.11.El cerebro tarda mucho en formarse por completo. En la adolescencia, solo se ha completado el 80% del cableado cerebral (lo cual puede que no sea una sorpresa para los padres de adolescentes). Aunque la mayor parte del crecimiento cerebral se produce en los primeros dos años de vida y termina en un 95% a los diez, las sinapsis no están completamente interconectadas hasta que la persona tiene entre veinticinco y treinta años.Eso significa que, en la práctica, la adolescencia se prolonga hasta bien entrada la edad adulta. Mientras tanto, la persona en cuestión tendrá un comportamiento más impulsivo y menos reflexivo que sus mayores y asimismo será más susceptible a los efectos del alcohol. "El cerebro adolescente no es solo un cerebro adulto con menos kilómetros", escribía en 2008 la profesora de neurología Frances E. Jensen en Harvard Magazine.12.Probablemente haya pocas circunstancias más inesperadas en relación a nuestro cerebro que el hecho de que en la actualidad este resulte ser más pequeño que hace 10.000 y 12.000, y no poco. Concretamente, desde entonces el cerebro medio se ha reducido de 1.500 a 1.350 cm3, lo que equivale a eliminar una porción de cerebro del tamaño de una pelota de tenis.Esta diferencia no resulta nada fácil de explicar, puesto que sucedió en todo el mundo al mismo tiempo, como si todos nosotros hubiéramos acordado reducir los cerebros en virtud de un tratado. La creencia generalizada es que nuestro cerebro simplemente se ha vuelto más eficiente y capaz de concentrar un mayor rendimiento en un espacio más pequeño, de manera similar a los teléfonos móviles, que se han ido haciendo cada vez más solicitados conforme se han ido reduciendo de tamaño. Pero nadie puede demostrar que lo que ha ocurrido no es sencillamente que nos hemos vuelto más tontos.13.Broca (...) estaba convencido, pese a tener todas las evidencias en contra, de que las mujeres, los criminales y los extranjeros de piel oscura tenían cerebros pequeños y menos ágiles que los hombres de raza blanca y conducta honesta. Cada vez que Broca se topaba con alguna evidencia que contradecía esa opinión, la ignoraba aduciendo que seguramente adolecía de alguna deficiencia. Tampoco se mostró dispuesto a creer los resultados de un estudio realizado en Alemania que revelaba que, por término medio, los cerebro de los alemanes pesaban 100 gramos más que los de los franceses. Broca explicó aquella incómoda discrepancia sugiriendo que los sujetos franceses eran muy viejos cuando fueron evaluados y, en consecuencia, sus cerebros se habían encogido. (...) También tuvo problemas para explicar por qué a veces los criminales a los que se ejecutaba tenían cerebros grandes y decidió que sus cerebros se habían hinchado artificialmente debido al estrés del ahorcamiento. Pero la mayor indignidad de todas se produjo cuando se midió el propio cerebro de Broca tras su muerte y se descubrió que era más pequeño que la media.14.Experimentamos el mundo que nuestro cerebro nos permite experimentar.15. Cuando la ciencia dice cosas que alguna gente no quiere que diga.El descubrimiento más inquietante de Atwater - tanto para él mismo como para el mundo en general - fue que el alcohol era un producto especialmente rico en calorías y, en consecuencia, resultaba ser un eficiente combustible. Como hijo de clérigo y él mismo abstemio, le horrorizaba tener que informar tal hallazgo, pero como diligente científico consideró que su principal compromiso era con la verdad, por incómoda que resultara.Por tal motivo, fue rápidamente repudiado por su propia universidad, devotamente metodista y su ya desdeñoso rector.16.Sea lo que fuere que nos da el sueño, es algo más que un mero periodo de inactividad reparadora. Tiene que haber algo que nos lleve a ansiar ardientemente quedar a mercer de posibles ataques de bandido o depredadores: sin embargo, que sepamos, dormir no hace nada por nosotros que no pudiera hacerse igualmente estando despiertos, pero en reposo.Tampoco sabemos por qué pasamos gran parte de la noche experimentando esas surrealistas y a menudo inquietantes alucinaciones a las que llamamos sueños. Ser perseguidos por zombies o encontrarse inexplicablemente desnudos en una parada de autobús no parece, a primera vista, una forma especialmente reconstituyente de pasar las horas de oscuridad.17.El período más largo que alguien ha pasado sin dormir de forma voluntaria se produjo en diciembre de 1963, cuando un estudiante de secundaria de San Diego de diecisiete años llamado Randy Gardner logró mantener despierto durante 264,4 horas (once días y veinticuatro minutos) en el marco de un proyecto escolar de ciencias.Los primeros días fueron relativamente fáciles para él, pero poco a poco se fue volviendo irritable y sumiéndose en un estado de confusión hasta que toda su existencia fue una especie de alucinación borrosa. Cuando terminó el proyecto, Gardner se derrumbó en la cama y durmió catorce horas seguidas. "Recuerdo que cuando desperté me sentía aturdido, pero no más que una persona normal", le diría a un entrevistador de la cadena de la radio NPR en 2017. Sus pautas de sueño volvieron a la noramlidad y no sufrió secuelas visibles. Sin embargo, años después experimento un terrible insomnio, que él consideró una "retribución kármica" por su aventura juvenil.18.Curiosamente, lo cierto es que el sexo no es necesario y de hecho muchos organismos han renunciado a él. Los gecos, esos pequeños largartos verdes que en los trópicos es frecuente ver aferrados a las paredes como juguetes de baño provistos de ventosas, han eliminado por completo a los machos.Resulta una idea un tanto inquietante si eres hombre, pero el hecho es que resulta fácil prescindir de lo que aportamos a la fiesta de la procreación. Los gecos producen huevos que son clones de la madre, y estos se convierten en una nueva generación de gecos. Desde la perspectiva de la madre, esta es una solución excelente, ya que significa que se heredan el 100% de sus genes.Con el sexo convencional, cada pareja transmite solo la mitad de sus genes, y esa proporción se va reduciendo incesantemente con cada nueva generación: nuestros nietos tendrán solo una cuarta parte de nuestros genes; nuestros bisnietos, una octava parte y así sucesivamente. Si ambicionamos la inmortalidad genética desde luego el sexo constituye una forma muy poco apropiada de lograrlo. (...)Puede que el sexo diluya nuestra contribución personal a la posteridad, pero resulta excelente para la especie. Al mezclar y combinar genes, obtenemos variedad y esta nos proporciona seguridad y resiliencia. Hace que resulte más difícil que las enfermedades se propaguen a poblaciones enteras. También implica que podemos evolucionar: podemos conservar los genes beneficiosos y descartar los que impiden nuestra felicidad colectiva. La clonación produce lo mismo una y otra vez. El sexo produce a Einstein y a Rembrandt y también, obviamente, a un montón de idiotas.19. PROFÉTICO. Aunque más que profecía, es ciencia.Lo cierto es que en realidad hoy no estamos mejor preparados para afrontar un brote que cuando la gripe española mató a decenas de millones de personas hace cien años. La razón por la que no hemos tenido otra experiencia así no es porque hayamos estado especialmente atentos. Es porque hemos tenido suerte.20. Sobre Calment, la mujer más anciana (verificada) que ha habido hasta ahora.Calment también se benefició de uno de los acuerdos económicos más deliciosamente mal calibrados jamás hechos. En 1965, enfrentada a ciertas dificultades financieras, aceptó dejar su piso en herencia a un abogado a cambio de un pago mensual de 2.500 francos hasta su muerte. Como Calment tenía entones 90 años, parecía un trato bastante favorable para el abogado. Pero al final fue este el que murió primero, 30 años después de haber firmado el acuerdo y tras haber abonado a Calment más de 900.000 francos por un piso que nunca llegaría a ocupar.21.Algunas personas viven más de que teóricamente deberían, teniendo en cuenta las circunstancias. Como señala Jo Marchant en su libro "Cúrate", los costarricenses tienen solo una quinta parte de la riqueza personal de los estadounidenses y una atención médica más deficiente, pero aún así, viven más tiempo. Asimismo, los habitantes de una de las regiones más pobres de Costa Rica, la península de Nicoya, son los que más viven de todo el país, a pesar de que tienen tasas mucho más altas de obesidad e hipertensión. Además cuentan con telómeros más largos.La teoría es que tienen lazos familiares y relaciones más estrechos que les resultan beneficiosos. Curiosamente, se ha descubierto que si viven solos, o no ven a un hijo al menos una vez por semana, la ventaja de la longitud de los telómeros desaparece. Es un hecho extraordinario que tener unas relaciones buenas y afectuosas altere físicamente a tu ADN. De manera inversa, un estudio realizado en 2010 en Estados Unidos reveló que carecere de tales relaciones duplica el riesgo de morir de cualquier cosa.UF, UNA BIBLIA AL FINAL SAQUÉ DE CITAS. Jajaja.

Bill Bryson is a gifted author for presenting profound concepts fully suffused with humour. He does this often so effortlessly that the readers cherish the opportunity to read one of his books. I am really a fan of him, having read many of his other works. This book is about the human body, the long-suffering servant of the soul. The various subsystems and functions of the body are examined in a light-hearted and appealing way. It deals with birth and death, organs from the skin to the brain, activities like breathing and digestion and how we came to acquire the knowledge of them historically. This book is the easiest way for a lay reader to comprehend what is going on inside and outside our frame and more importantly, to marvel at the working of this wonderful artifact of eons of evolution. It is also to be noted that though the body appears to be arranged neat and tidy from the outside, the inside is haphazard and messy at times.The sense of awe and wonder one feels at the mechanisms that regulate various body parameters is immense. The way white blood cells attack pathogens, how dead cells are replenished in many organs but not all, the mechanism of hearing or vision are all so complicated that people who ascribe an all-powerful creator behind this magic may reasonably be pardoned. You see Bryson exclaiming with wonder, “and you can appreciate what an accomplished creation we are”! You should forgive the author for the remark on ‘creation’ which is used here only as a figure of speech. Bryson is devoted to evolution as the raison d’etre of all lifeforms. He calmly explains how the miraculous functions of a human body part are only an extension of a comparable organ in animals more closely related to humans. It is this solid foundation on modern rational thought that makes this work a pleasure to read. With this underpinning on science, you feel confident to recommend the book to others, especially with impressionable minds.We know that modern science has collected a vast amount of knowledge about the human body, especially on its response to extreme stimulants over the centuries. The author notes that some of it might have come from the gruesome clinical experiments carried out by Nazi doctors on their unfortunate Jewish prisoners or that by Japanese military physicians on Chinese and other prisoners of war during World War II. In Nazi Germany, healthy prisoners were subjected to amputation or experimental limb implants in the hopes of finding better treatments for German casualties. Russian prisoners were plunged into icy water to determine how long a German pilot could survive a downing at sea. Some experiments were driven by nothing more than morbid curiosity. In one, the subject’s eyes were injected with dyes to see if their eye colour could be permanently changed. In fact, many doctors were not forced to perform such experiments, they just volunteered.Bryson not only asserts that evolution is the only plausible mechanism that could bring about the complexity in lifeforms, but attacks Intelligent Design with examples of inconsistencies and ‘not-so-intelligent’ design. If ever there was an event that challenged the concept of Intelligent Design, it is the act of childbirth, in which a large head is passing through a much smaller constriction which came about as a byproduct of bipedalism. The author quips that ‘no woman, however devout, has ever in childbirth said, “Thank you, Lord, for thinking this through for me”. Then, there is a slight inconsistency in the narrative, which, if not cleared by experts would confuse the readers much. The book claims that the moment of birth is quite a miracle. In the womb, the foetus’ lungs are filled with amniotic fluid, but with exquisite timing, at the moment of birth, the fluid drains away, the lungs inflate and blood from the tiny heart is sent on its first circuit around the body (p.299). But in the caption to a colour plate of a foetus of six weeks, it is said that its heart is beating at hundred beats per minute. Is it circulating amniotic fluid through the veins at that time?This book provides clear warnings for health-conscious readers. Coconut oil is said to be essentially nothing but saturated fat in liquid form. It may be tasty, but it is no better than a big scoop of deep fried butter (p.244). This is indeed very bad news for people in Kerala where we know of no other oil than that which is extracted from the hardy coconut and used for practically all purposes like bathing, cooking, cosmetics and others. The text also includes detailed description of diseases that affect us and the precautions that can be taken against them. The pharma industry’s relentless pursuit of finding cures for diseases is also commented upon. However, the author leaves a hint that many germs have by now attained resistance to common antibiotics and future diseases could become more virulent. He warns that the reason we haven’t had another disastrous experience like the Spanish Flu isn’t because we have been especially vigilant, but because we have been lucky (p.335). It is a strange coincidence that just a few months after the publication of this book, Covid 19 struck the world with a devastating trail of death and misery.One sad fact you’d observe in this latest book from Bryson is the absence of his immensely enjoyable humour. Every page of his previous books had made the readers smile with witty remarks, but not this one. This book is definitely valuable, but only for the tons of useful information packed between its covers and arranged in meaningful chapters. It rightly deserves the epithet of a popular science book, but that’s not the richly fulfilling experience a reader expects from Bryson. Anyhow, the personal touch can still be felt, and the last paragraph would make you ponder on the meaning of life itself. It runs like this: ‘The average grave is visited only for about fifteen years, so most of us take a lot longer to vanish from the earth than from others’ memories. If you are cremated, your ashes will weigh about two kilograms. And that’s you gone. But it was good while it lasted, wasn’t it?’The book is highly recommended.

This was a solid read!In this book, Bill Bryson goes through all of the major functions of the body, from the skin, to your brain, to all the way to death. It was a fun read, and really accessible! What I liked the most was getting to know more about how things got discovered about our bodies, and learning about those scientists' lives. It was interesting to see how certain discoveries were mere accidents, and thus changed the world! All really fascinating stuff. This is a book I think I will be coming back to just to reread these interesting facts over again. One thing I will say is that I found that this book was a tad UK and USA biased, in a way that many of the facts that were displayed here were compared and contrasted with UK and USA stats. But, there were other parts that had interesting information from elsewhere in the world. The other criticism I have is that (and maybe this is a me thing) is that I kind of found myself already forgetting some of the interesting facts after finishing the book. Like, I feel like this book would've benefitted me way more if I annotated spots where I found interesting. But, I guess that just means I have an opportunity to come back to this book in the future!The audiobook was really good too. It's narrated by Bryson himself. The only thing that bothered me was that I was following along with my physical copy, and I noticed that there were many times where he would switch up the wording, or incorporate new material that's not in the printed copy in his narration. I had pretty mixed feelings about this book. I’m a big fan of Bryson as a humorist. I value a good laugh over many other things in life, and Bryson is one of the funniest people I’ve ever encountered. The Life and Times of the Thunderbolt kid is possibly the funniest book I’ve ever read in my entire life. I came across my first Bill Bryson book on the dusty shelf of a house in which I was staying in Europe a few years ago, it was The Lost Continent, Travels in Small-Town America. That book had me in splits for the rest of my trip and brought me so much joy. I still quote it on road trips in America. In short, I think Bryson excels as an essayist, a travel writer, and a humorist in general. But he has this other big passion, to catalogue. I enjoyed a Short History of Nearly Everything, but I went into this book with a rather more critical scientific eye because as a neuroscientist, my education is in the life sciences. The tone and writing of the book were excellent and entertaining, we already know Bryson is a dynamite writer. This book was totally enjoyable. But factually, I’m not as convinced. The book is impressive in its scope and detail, especially for a non-scientist, and Bryson’s joy in learning the material comes through robustly. However the actual biological information contained in this book is kind of a hodgepodge. Some sections are really well nuanced and do a great job of citing good primary resources. For example, the section on leptin was presented better than many endocrinology texts I’ve read, making it clear that leptin is a hormone that is thought to signal a paucity of body fat when it is low, and stimulates appetite to remedy the situation. Leptin does not work as a supplement for overweight people, because above a certain threshold, it does not affect appetite appreciably. It did not evolve to signal as a regulator of excessive weight gain. The section on the prostate was also really well presented. Bryson discusses at some length the false positive rate of many preventative cancer screenings, PSA among them. This section mostly draws on the work of Richard J Ablin, who invented the PSA test, making him a very appropriate primary resource. But then, throughout the book Bryson does things like cite Daniel Lieberman extensively about things like the biochemistry of nutrition, even though Lieberman’s education is in anthropology. He’s not an expert on any of the fields Bryson cites him for, he just speaks about them accessibly, and as a result, much of the factual content of these sections is questionable. As a neuroscientist, I took special issue with the portion on neurogenesis over the lifespan. Bryson claims that it is hotly debated whether humans make new brain cells as we age. This is not true, there is a strong consensus in neuroscience that new neurons are formed throughout the lifespan. Bryson points to two opposing studies, one finding that new neurons were made in the hippocampus, and others finding that they were not. This is a misinterpretation of the second study, which actually found that the new neurons in the hippocampus were formed elsewhere and migrated into the hippocampus. Additionally, he claims that whether or not we make new neurons is sort of a moot point because it is nowhere near enough to compensate for the rampant neuronal loss we experience with aging. This is completely untrue and based on studies largely conducted in the 1950’s-1970’s which did not correct for volumetric changes in the aging brain. The best evidence to date says that there is no significant neuronal loss associated with normal aging, or that we lose perhaps 2-4% of neurons over the lifespan in normal aging. While there is some shrinkage of neuronal outgrowths, cell loss is not typical outside of pathological conditions like Alzheimer’s disease. In short, this book is interesting, funny, and a charming read. But if something in it seems radical or hard to believe to you, I’d encourage investigating other primary sources of info about that topic.

I think for most of us Bill Bryson is an author we tend to associate with travel writing. I myself have spent a good few hours lost in his books. Throughout out, I have always been able to learn something of the places he has been to and also had a good laugh. This time he has turned his attention to a place a little closer to home. For all the time we spend in them, most of us know little about how the function. We all often take it for granted that they are doing what they are supposed to. Within this book, Bryson set out to give us a better understanding of just how our bodies work and for that matter keep working. The book is broken up into chapters dealing with different aspects of the human body. His aim seems to be to give us a brief understanding of each of there functions and at times how they can go very wrong. For me, this was a book that is a step or two up from your school textbooks. He gave me a better way to get into the material. In the process breaking down some of the bigger biological processes into much easier bites. More than once I was left feeling surprised at my own very limited knowledge on the subject. I think I can know peel off a great many facts to share with others. But as he admits for all we know of the human body we still have a great deal to learn. There are great swaths of information missing from our understanding. The human body is one of the most complex things and with each passing day, there are people out there in search of answers to all the questions he raises.  For a book that is very complex at times, Bryson try's his best to bring it to us on a level we can all understand. But with any such book, there will always be a great deal of information to take in. I am usually a fairly quick reader, but even for me, this book took a few days to make my way through. This is not such a bad thing I was able to stop at a certain point to delve a little deeper online and to think about what he was telling me. I would point out that his usual level of humor is missing from this book. While it does pop up from time to time. I feel this is more Bryson the educates than bubbling adventure. And while a great deal of the books is given over to just how we function, he also delves into what happens when it all goes wrong. In doing so he does not shy away from race and gender. He does his best to show that while on some levels we are all the same, these two factors I mentioned play a big deal in not only how our bodies react to illness but how we are treated when going to the hospital. I think I should count my self lucky to have grown up in Britain whilst we may not be on the top of any charters we are certainly nowhere near the bottom.  Having finished the book I appreciate this will not be one for everyone. I think a lot of die-hard Bryson fans will struggle to make it through. For me it was a great book to read, I'm always looking to expand my knowledge on all subjects. And to find one that helps me better understand my self can not be bad at all. This nook was never going to fill in all the blanks, but if you want to either refresh what you know or are looking to get a foothold in the subject of the human body Bryson is your man.

This book was a blast to read. Unoputdownable (I love that word). If you stopped to mark every interesting factoid, the entire book would be underlined. This must have been the easiest book in the world to write, especially for such a well-known and well-connected writer.   ***Going for regular walks reduces the risk of heart attack or stroke by 31 percent. An analysis of 655,000 people in 2012 found that being active for just eleven minutes a day after the age of forty yielded 1.8 years of added life expectancy. Being active for an hour or more a day improved life expectancy by 4.2 years. ***The fact is, you can quickly undo a lot of exercise by eating a lot of food, and most of us do. ***A study of eighteen thousand runners in Denmark concluded that people who jog regularly can expect to live five to six years longer on average than non-joggers. But is that because jogging truly is that beneficial, or is it because people who jog tend to lead healthy, moderate lives anyway and are bound to have improved outcomes over us more slothful types, with or without sweatpants? ***In one well-known experiment cited by the British academic Steve Jones, a test subject ran a marathon on a treadmill while the room temperature was gradually raised from minus 49 degrees Fahrenheit to 131 degrees Fahrenheit—roughly the limits of human tolerance at both extremes. Despite the subject’s exertions and the great range of temperatures, his core body temperature deviated by less than one degree over the course of the exercise. ***As an experiment, we asked a lady who was completely blind—she had lost her rods and cones as a result of a genetic disease—to tell us when she thought the lights in the room were switched on or off. She told us not to be ridiculous because she couldn’t see anything, but we asked her to try anyway. It turned out she was right every time. Even though she had no vision—no way of ‘seeing’ the light—her brain detected it with perfect fidelity at a subliminal level. She was astonished. We all were.” ***As the American academic Marlene Zuk has put it, “Old age is not a recent invention, but its commonness is.”
