I have been a Bill Bryson fan for quite some time. I first read A Short History of Nearly Everything when it came out, and I was stunned at how much I understood and liked science. I even understood string theory for a total of about six minutes. But it was something!I have been on the Bryson tip since then, usually with rewarding results. I have loved his books on travel, the English language, Shakespeare, and more. I couldn’t quite get into At Home, but I think I might want to retry that one, because I loved this book. It does everything that a listicle will do for your sense of understanding, but probes deeper and casts a wider net. It is so much more interesting than those pithy articles from the Internet.We get to almost all of it: birth and death, sight and taste, emotion and sex. Some of the historical names get lost in the morass, but that doesn’t matter so much if, when you’re reading it, it compels you this deeply. And indeed it compels, giving us history of communicable diseases, the dividing line between when a zygote becomes a baby, and how, exactly, my color blind eyes work.There should be a tendency to get grim. There are so many statistics, so many I don’t knows, that it might be simpler for Bryson to simply shrug and say science doesn’t know much. But one of Bryson’s strengths is that he loves to follow footnotes to sources. The Body is thorough; but that doesn’t mean it’s dry. I listened to the audiobook read by Bryson himself. I love his orating voice, and the way he emphasizes certain words in his half-British/half-American accent. He is very good at what he does here, in both delivery and content. If you really like Brysons earlier work, I highly recommend trying this one out. You won’t regret it.

Bill Bryson es otro de mis candidatos a ser considerado “el hombre más interesante del mundo”, pero a diferencia de Alberto Manguel o de Pratchett, tiene entre sus hazañas el haber sido interpretado en la película por Robert Redford (al que no se parece nada pero en fin).Esta vez no hablamos del espacio exterior, el cosmos y todo lo demás. Tampoco del espacio doméstico y sus particularidades. Esta vez es sobre el espacio interior, su estructura y funcionamiento en una carrera frenética de quinientas páginas mas cien de apéndices y notas. Nos cuenta lo sorprendente de nuestro organismo y nos recorre por la historia de la medicina para resaltar los grandes progresos, los difíciles retos pendientes y las tendencias preocupantes. El libro es de Octubre de 2019, así que el capítulo sobre epidemias resulta ligeramente tener un humor negro al decir que no se sabe cuándo la siguiente ‘grande’ está a la vuelta de la esquina.El libro es espléndido para repasar las clases de educación para la salud, y también para recordar una larga caterva de libros de divulgación muy populares, cuyas principales ideas se vuelven a exponer aquí (Sapiens, Nacidos para Correr, Blink, Pensar Rápido/Pensar Despacio, El Emperador de todos los Males, Por qué dormimos, Glup, De Matasanos a Cirujanos, La Mujer Invisible, Ser Mortal, Hasta las Cenizas). El único punto menos es algo que me imagino es característica de Bryson: Es. Demasiada. Información. No recuerdo prácticamente nada de En Casa, el único otro libro que he leído de él, y aquí fuera de lo que ya sabía no creo que recuerde mucho. De todas formas es no ficción apasionante.

My first book by Bill Bryson was "A Short History of Nearly Everything." Since reading it, I have frequently included a Bryson book or two in my yearly reading and have suggested them to others. The Body is sure to be another book I will regularly recommend (and in fact already have).The book itself winds through the system's of the body one after another. Bryson discusses what makes up the system, the important discoveries and discovers of parts in the system, always with an eye toward what makes for a good story. Finishing with the systems, he moves on to the functions of the body, illness and causes of disease, and finally death. Even knowing a good amount about anatomy and scientific history, I found myself learning while reading things book. This was particularly true when he discussed new research and interviews with scientists on the cutting edge of physiology or disease research. However, don't mistake this as a boring textbook. While this does not contain the wit and sarcasm of his travelogues or even Brief History, Bryson has a style of writing that keeps you engaged and reading well past the time when you should have gone to bed. I recommend this book for anyone interested in anatomy in particular or science as a whole. You are sure to learn something and have fun doing it. Thank you to the publisher and Netgalley for the opportunity to read a pre-release copy this book.

I imagine Bill Bryson standing in front of a mirror doing his thing, with a sudden moment of clarity one day--I know nothing at all about this body of mine. Let me find out more. This book is what I imagine would be the outcome of that moment. This is a sweeping and wide-ranging account of your body from head to toe (with cameos by the various non-human organisms that make us who we are). Bryson chooses to focus on facts and stories--what we know, and how we came to know this, which makes for some very engaging stories. Some themes recur throughout--how a lot of what we assume is common knowledge is myth (8 glasses of water a day, using only 10% of our brain, our body having 10 times more microbes as human cells), how we cannot trust corporates to do the right thing (the opioid crisis, the food industry shoving bad things down our throats, the lobbying by the tobacco industry), and just how little we truly understand when we dig deeper (how does an itch arise?) It's a tome for sure, but the length feels just right. If there was anything I had a problem with, it was the author's focus on the White world--there is a touch of Euro/America centrism that feels outdated in this age.

I have really enjoyed most of Bill Bryson's books but really struggled to find anything likeable about this one. I normally finish a book in 2 days and this took me 25 days to finish because I kept putting it down. He lists some facts about each area of the body and the scientists that studied it, whether those facts are interesting or not. Sometimes he gets into the subject matter and briefly writes in an engaging way, but most of the time it reads like a list of bullet points he jotted down while reading something else. He cribs very heavily from Mary Roach's works and always gives her credit but trust me, it's more fun and engaging to read her amazing books directly instead of this summary of Bill's. It's tedious, I felt like most of the facts were obvious things I learned in primary school or summaries from better books I had already read, and found his super repetitive negative comments about fat people a bit hypocritical and mean. I've already had 2 of my home library clients return it and say they didn't like it and couldn't finish it, so I am not going to recommend it to anyone.

I REALLY liked this book. I am biased because in my imagination Bill Bryson is a friend with whom I chat often and from whom I learn all sorts of fascinating things. In reality, Mr Bryson is an author whom I’ve never met but who entertained me for the last two and a half months with facts about the human body that I have repeated aloud so often to friends and family that every time they find my words interesting they ask me if I learned it from “your Body Book”. Most of the time the answer was yes. I learned so many things in each and every chapter. Perhaps the most important to me was that a person cannot “undo sitting” or negate its detrimental effects on the body by activity or exercise. As a result of this singular fact, I read many of these 400 pages while standing. True fact. This is one of those books that at the end I am better off, mind and body, as it happens, for having read!

Скажу так - я для себе мало що нового тут прочитала, в силу своєї біологічної освіти. Але якщо ви не навчалися на біологічному чи в меді, то тут буде безліч нового та цікавого. Книга поділена на тематичні розділи, на приклад "Мозок" "Шкіра і волосся" "Серце і кров" "Імунна система", тощо. Всередині розділів ви не знайдете шкільних пояснень як все працює. Тобто мінімальна база знань у вас все ж має бути. Тут безліч цікавих фактів та історій на цю тему. Як на мене - все базується на доказовій науці та медицині. Автор справді заморочився - використано понад 700 джерел, більшість з яких є науковими працями та консультувався зі спеціалістами. Читається легко, без наукової важкості тексту. Стиль легкий та дотепний.

Enter the wonderful world of Bill Bryson who has a master's touch for explaining things in a way that we all understand and are fascinated by. When he takes apart our body, system by system, piece by piece we not only understand more about our inner workings but we have been thoroughly entertained along the way. He is the master of anecdote, the king of clever tidbits of knowledge and easygoing writing style gives you a greater appreciation for the intricate machine we call our body. Here's to not-stuffy science! My thanks to the publisher for the advance copy.

What Bill Bryson did for the home, in his book "At Home: A Short History of Private Life", he now does for the human body in "The Body: A Guide for Occupants." This books is full of wonderful and sometimes quirky facts about the human body. Great as a fun read, and it's quite comprehensive in depth of the human body. As Bill Gates said, "The human body is the most complex system ever created. The more we learn about it, the more appreciation we have about what a rich system it is."*I read an advance copy and was not compensated.

One of my favorite books of the year! Bryson made me appreciate how amazing and wonderful our bodies truly are. It is a miracle that each one of us have the opportunity to live. I appreciated how it went area-by-area through the body including some analyses of the lesser appreciated functions like equilibrium, sleep, and more.I think the title "a guide for occupants" lives up to its name. If you have an interest in your body and/or human medicine, this is an incredibly entertaining and accessible guide.

This was fairly good; pretty standard Bryson. There were plenty of chuckles, and lots of OH MY GOD SERIOUSLY? I don't think the bar is high for that, because the body is wow no matter what. But one of Bryson's serious talents is to distill big things down to understandable chunks, and he definitely succeeds in that here.But also, there is a LOT LOT LOT of fatphobia in this book. Like so much I *almost* put it down. So I don't know, if you're triggered by that, definitely avoid this.

Всичко, което съм чела от този автор, си е струвало и тази поредна негова книга не прави изключение. Шеметна разходка из човешкото тяло от раждането до смъртта му, от клетката през тъканта до органа и системата... и нито секунда скука. Някак много си пасвам с Бил Брайсън, сигурно защото и двамата сме леко досадни любители на странната тривия. Защо имаме вкусови рецептори в тестисите или в белия дроб? Не знаем, но колко изумително интересно ми се вижда това... :)

Fun, Bryson-y...but I'm not sure there's anything in here I haven't encountered elsewhere--Mary Roach and many others spring to mind as examples of writers who've covered the same territory. (Bryson, indeed, quotes Roach quite a bit.)The fault here may lie partially with me: I have perhaps read too many pop science books.

Yet another excellent read from this author - I just love his style of writing that is informative and understandable without the tendency to baffle the reader with science, which I often find with books of this sort. Thoroughly entertaining and thought-provoking - 9/10.

Had to dip in and out of this, it’s not something (for me at least), to go at all at once. Especially in audio format. I found myself performing all sorts of self-examination procedures on the way to work. Arrestable offences in some parts of the country. Rather good all the same.
Funny, smart, entertaining, and thoughtful. A great read for people who like Mary Roach.

Якщо кожен раз пити, коли з’являються в цій книжці фрази «ми не знаємо», «ніхто не знає» і тд, то можна нормально так мекнути в процесі:)І хоч дійсно ми ой як багато ще всього не знаємо про наше тіло, я дуже рада, що з кожним днем дізнаємось все більше. А то трішки нажахали історії минулого з дослідженнями і лікуванням (так, окреме дякую за ілюстрації цього). А взагалі класний підручник з анатомії, сподобалось.

Super interesting and filled with weird information about the human body, just what I wanted. My only qualm with this book is that it's just constant facts and almost too much information to digest as you read it. It may be better to read in increments or use as a reference.

I listened to this audiobook read by Bill Bryson as I went to and from work. It was excellent. So excellent that I am buying myself a copy of the book.I wasn’t sure if I’d be so interested in hearing about the body (and he covers everything) but I ended up finding so much of it fascinating! I kept thinking “wow that’s incredible… I never knew that… I should read more about that…”I highly recommend this book. You can’t help but find it interesting!

This book should replace the current biology textbooks at schools. It's much more accurate, up-to-date AND extremely interesting. I feel that I have learnt more about human body than I ever did during all my school years (a long time ago). The author gives us a tour of the human body through all its systems such as integumentary system, nervous system and respiratory system. We explore the role of every single element of the body, we learn about how we came to have the current medical knowledge and what we are still missing, as well as about everything that can go wrong in the marvelous yet imperfect machine that the human body is.The author focuses a lot on people to whom we owe everything we know today. Many of the geniuses that propelled the medical knowledge forward were often very flawed or outright horrible people outside of their profession. It gives perspective on the people that refuse to read extraordinary books written by morally doubtful writers. It's about separating people from their work.What I found the most terrifying just how much we still don't know about our own bodies. We can do close to nothing about autoimmune diseases (which I was unfortunately already aware of, since I myself suffer from one), cancer and other things in pretty every single human system.There were also many facinating trivia facts, for example: - Autoimmune diseases are "sexist" and 80% of sufferers are women. - Many women needlessly die of heart attacks, because they are misdiagnosed due to the male bias in what we know about the symptoms (women often have completely different symptoms than men!). - The race, which has played and unfortunately still plays such a huge role in human history and modern time, is nothing but a thin layer of cells in the outer skin. - The idea of growing human organs in animals for transplanting gave a creepy Oryx and Crake vibe *shudders*. - Humans enjoy animal suffering. They torture animal in labs and they call it animal testing. The problem is that animals are different species than humans and they have very different metabolism, suffer from different diseases, etc. So people inflict horrible suffering on them, and there are no real benefits for humanity, apart from sadists enjoying themselves. And guess where a lot of worst diseases come from, including the biggest epidemics? Animal farming. Karma is a bitch. *munches on a vegan burger* Except we all suffer for the pleasure of meat-eaters' taste buds. - Cancerous cells appear in our bodies a few times a week and are promptly detected and destroyed by our immune system. Until they aren't. If we live long enough, we pretty much all get cancer. Scary…
Personal note
So this is a note for my future self, to give the interesting context in which I was reading this book. As I write this review, we are right in the middle of Covid-19 pandemic. I didn't plan on reading a medical non-fiction featuring diseases and epidemics now. I was waiting in the library queue for this book for a few months, long before anyone suspected what times we would find ourselves in. My hold finally arrived when the first news about unknown virus in China started spreading around the world. I got opportunity to read this book slowly instead of hurrying through (since renewal for popular books is not possible), because the national lock-down happened, the libraries closed from day to day and I was left with all my check-outs for unknown amount of time. As such, when I reached the chapter about infectious diseases, I was in my third (or fourth?) week of working from home, just as most of the people who were fortunate not to lose their jobs. And then this quotation came up: The fact is, we are really no better prepared for a bad outbreak today than we were when Spanish flu killed tens of millions of people a hundred years ago. The reason we haven't had another experience like that isn't because we have been especially vigilant. It's because we have been lucky.Well, it seems that our luck has finally run out…

С тази книга авторът умело достига до широка аудитория, обяснявайки в детайли всеки механизъм и функция на човешкото тяло. Прави го по един непринуден и на много места шеговит начин, който разтоварва текста от иначе сериозните медицински и биологични факти и терминология, които често се оказват трудно предизвикателство за такива като мен, четящи предимно художествена литература.

Like many readers, I very much enjoy Bill Bryson's non-fiction work.  I picked up his newest publication, The Body: A Guide for Occupants having not read any of his writing for such a long time, and was so pleased that I did.  I was reminded once more of how warm his prose is, and how fascinating his subjects.Many of Bryson's books are essentially travel writing, in which he writes about countries and regions which he has lived or travelled within - the United States, United Kingdom, and Africa are just three examples.  The Body is something a little different to these personal geographies, though.  It is far more science-based than much of his work, and does not include many personal stories, something which his books tend to be built upon.  It looks inward, trying to decipher what really makes a human being.The Body has been split into many chapters, each of which focuses upon a distinctive part of the human body.  These range from 'The Immune System' and 'The Brain' to 'Into the Nether Regions'.  These chapters are incredibly thorough; there is not an element of the body which has not been explored in some way.  He moves seamlessly from one topic to another.  With his chapter on the skin, for instance, he moves from bacteria found on the skin to the phenomenon of itching, and then the reasons as to why we lose hair as we age, all in less than two pages.Bryson writes about so many things here, including the beginning of forensic science; microbes and proteins, and their functions and uses within the body; viruses; advances in medicine; evolutionary changes within human anatomy; how different parts of us age, and the consequences felt; the myriad benefits of exercise; and the wonder found within the structure of our bones.  He writes about so many things that are known about the human body, and also the surprising number of elements which remain a mystery.  Bryson introduces several medical conundrums, interesting cases which cannot be solved.Bryson has chosen to begin The Body with rather a fascinating chapter, entitled 'How to Build a Human', which calculates how expensive it would be to procure all of the elements which make up the human body - clue: a lot.  This memorable prologue, as it were, sets the tone for the book, and feels perfectly placed.As ever, Bryson's writing in The Body is both absorbing and accessible.  He grapples with complex ideas throughout the book, but presents everything in a way which can be read and understood by newcomers to this subject.  He introduces myriad facts in marvellous ways, which really make one think; for instance, 'In the second or so since you started this sentence, your body has made a million red blood cells.'  One can see from the outset that Bryson clearly has quite a passion for this subject, and this shines throughout, as does his humour.  Throughout, Bryson consults experts in different fields, and also mentions a lot of books which focus upon biology along the way.The Body is a book which one can learn, unsurprisingly, a great deal from.  I have always been fascinated by biology and the human body, and have read a few books on the subject before, but I found myself learning new facts throughout.  Although there is such a great deal packed into the pages of The Body, and a great deal of impeccable research has clearly been done, it never feels saturated with information, and can easily be read from cover to cover.  The Body is, all in all, a fact-lover's dream, which demonstrates how wonderful the human body is, in all of its strangeness.I will end this review with a passage which I, personally, found fascinating: 'The most remarkable part of all is your DNA.  You have a metre of it packed into every cell, and so many cells that if you formed all the DNA in your body into a single fine strand it would stretch ten billion miles, to beyond Pluto.  Think of it: there is enough of you to leave the solar system.  You are in the most literal sense cosmic.'

An absolutely brilliant book by Bill Bryson.Book is written in simple words. It carefully avoids scientific jargons to make it engaging for uninitiated persons like me. So it is basically a book for everyone. Right from the start, a continuous feeling of amazement regarding the painstaking efforts taken by the author to create a lucid compendium about the most complex and at the same time most fascinating living machine created by this natural world - the Human Body, accompanied me. This evocative book contains interesting facts, surprising histories regarding anatomical and medical knowledge - how the scientifically curious forbears came upon various levels of knowledge we possess regarding our body, some clarifying informations to dispel some of the commonly held myths/misconceptions about our body and much more.It takes us along a long, fascinating, surprising and at times deeply thoughtful journey. I thoroughly enjoyed the above said journey. It is a must-read for every curious minds out there.Do not miss it fellow readers.Finally a Huge Thanks to the author for using his invaluable time and effort to produce this book.
Typical Bill Bryson: well-written, humorous, and extremely informative!

I have read - and enjoyed - several of Bryson's earlier books, so his name always catches my eye. This one, his latest, is not at all a memoir, but instead a rather comprehensive view of human biology. This overview touches on many subjects - from the specifics of diseases, impacts of lifestyle choices, details on how organs function alongside quick biographical highlights of many Novel prize winners and others who have made significant discoveries in medicine and deepening your understanding of your own body.There is a lot crammed into this volume - with many interesting footnotes, anecdotes and facts that are fun to share as you read along. The chapters are clearly broken down by subject and though there are a few references to information revealed in later or earlier chapters, for the most part, there isn't even a reason to read this consecutively (so if you are the most interested in the heart - start there!). I think this would be a perfect book to slowly read - a friend of mine mentions that she has a few books always on the go like that (one on her nightstand for just before bed reading, another in the car for reading while waiting on her kids in the pick up line). Because I did read it consecutively, without breaks, it did stand out that Bryson really stressed the poor health of America over his adopted country of Great Britain. I don't think this would have been as obvious had I read this more slowly, over a longer period of time. It is an interesting read and one that definitely feels well-researched. I can see this as a nice addition to your home reference library. And I am curious to see what direction Bryson will go in next.

I never would have guessed that a book about the human body could be so interesting. I loved this book as it had so much great information. If you just want to read a thousand interesting facts, this is the book for you.-1.6% of of all good exported in the U.S. are sales of plasma-The sense of smell is the only one of the five basic senses not mediated by the hypothalamus. Information instead goes straight to the olfactory cortex. Smell also accounts for 70% of flavor. - In one well known experiment, a test subject ran a marathon on a treadmill while the room temperature gradually raised from -49 degrees Fahrenheit to 131 degrees. The runners core body temperature deviated by less than one degree over the course of the exercise.- From 1973 to 2011, the average sperm count in Western nations fell by more than 50 percentThe book also has a lot of history about how discoveries regarding the human body were made. Many of them were accidental. Others were more malicious. I had previously read about the horrific experiments conducted by Nazi scientists during WWII on prisoners and Jews but until this book, I was unaware that the Japanese did the same thing against the Chinese during the war at a location called Unit 731 in which it's estimated that 250 thousand people died. One of the most interesting non-fiction books I've ever read. I'd recommend it to anyone

Bill Bryson, through extensive reading, has compiled a book all about the body. He outlines the history of acquiring knowledge from the most conceivable moment up to the present day, citing the discoveries of various parts of the body when they occurred and by whom. Myths are dispelled such as taking vitamin C will help get rid of a cold or that we need to drink eight glasses of water a day. He discusses practices to help an individual live a healthy, quality of life such as couch potatoes (those sitting six or more hours a day) can benefit by walking around during commercials to burn 180 calories an hour or just standing to burn 107 calories an hour. Recommendations by the World Health Organization such as the daily recommendation for sugar intake is a maximum of five teaspoons are also presented. A muliitude of diseases have come and gone, only to replaced by another disease such as the Heartland virus in 2018. Now there is the Coronavirus which is new since the publication of The Body. How operations have evolved over the years with some horrendous descriptions of earlier operations such as the mastectomy of Fanny Burney, an English novelist, in 1810. Bryson reiterates Daniel E. Lieberman, professor of human evolutionary biology at Harvard: belief that 70 percent of the diseases that kill us could easily be preventable if we would just live sensibly.

4.5 starsAdvance copy provided by NetGalley.At the beginning, I was a bit overwhelmed by the waterfall of facts descending upon me, but once I settled into his style, I really enjoyed this. Besides the abundance of facts about human anatomy, a subject I felt I needed to learn more about, there’s fascinating medical history and biographical information about pioneers in the field of medicine. What struck me most in this book is that so many discoveries and theories that are common knowledge today were initially rejected. Scientists whose ideas were initially met with scorn were later awarded Nobel prizes. Another rather chilling recurring theme of the book is how little we know about the body, aging, and diseases, even in this modern age when we’re supposed to have it all figured out (right?). His notes and bibliography at the end are impressive, and I plan to use the latter as a source for future reading material. There’s a lot of territory to cover, so nothing is terribly in-depth, but the book is an interesting, thought-provoking overview of what we know so far about what makes us tick.

I have been wanting to read Bill Bryson for a while now and was thrilled when I got this ebook from my library. Timing is everything and I was the first person to check it out at my library! The book is filled with amazing facts and stories about how the human body works, medical science, and the history of medicine. The author's particular writing style, relaying all these science facts within anecdotal stories, is what makes it so entertaining and fun to read. And it definitely helps with my retention of scientific information, especially as I get older! Several parts of the book were devoted to the brain, memory and aging, so, yes, I am sure I was his target audience! My main take-away from this book is despite all our advances and increased knowledge of the human body, we really know so little and so much of what we know is still theory and guesswork. I highly recommend The Body. It reminds me of Mary Roach's writing style. I will be looking out for more books by Bill Bryson.

Intetesting and, in parts, fascinating. The most fascinating thing is that Bryson marvels at the incredible human body yet sadly attributes everything solely to evolution and won't even consider the possibility of it all pointing to a creator God.

Bill Bryson is a gifted writer, deftly melding facts with wit to expose humorous aspects of the human condition and the world around us. As a result, he can unpack any topic into the most fascinating thing you’ve ever read. The Body: A Guide for Occupants is no exception. Each chapter focuses on a body part or process, similar to the format of his book At Home focusing on the house and its functions. As with his other books, he has a knack for tracking down mind-boggling statistics and facts. So while some of these you may recall from biology class, he manages to find other intricate details and relays them in a clear, witty manner. And while we have come such a long way in learning and discovering the body's inner workings, there's much that's still a mystery to medical science. I just kept thinking, "Wow - this is the place that houses all of my thoughts, feelings and physical attributes and there's still so much I don't know about it." We truly are a work in progress.

Bill's humor and cleverness seems packed into the first 25% of this book. After that, it becomes a slog through each body system in turn, with fact after fact piling up, none of it very thorough. For better writing about gut microbes, read Ed Yong's wonderful _I Contain Multitudes: The Microbes Within Us and a Grander View of Life_. For better writing about sex and reproduction, read Mary Roach's _Bonk_ or _Everything Below the Waist: Why Health Care Needs a Feminist Revolution_. For better writing about humanity's upright gait and long-distance running capacity, read _Born to Run_. Basically, for every topic covered superficially here, there's a better, more entertaining book. That said, this is a *great* survey of the major systems, and I'll be happy to let my kids read it when they're ready for such a good overview.

Pravdepodobne ta nejzabavnejsi popularne-naucna kniha, kterou jsem zatim cetla, zatim v tesnem zavesu za "Strucnou historii" stejneho autora.Pruvodce lidskym telem vas pouci nejenom o anatomii, kde, co, proc a jak funguje, ale navrch prihazuje jeste hromadu zajimavych cisel a statistik, historickych kuriozit a temnych historek na dane tema. Za obzvlast vypecenou povazuju tu o prvnim vyzkumu lidskeho zaludku.Zopakujete si skolni biologii a dozvite se spoustu veci nad jeji ramec. Zaverecne kapitoly se venuji nikoli telesnym organum a funkcim, ale nemocim, rakovine a smrti. Pokud vam je tezko se takovymi myslenkami zaobirat (jako je tezko mne), mozna vam da konec trochu zabrat. Ale navzdory tomu, ze je Bryson nekdy morbidni, vzdycky je morbidni s laskavosti a humorem. Oznacuju za stalici nasi knihovny a kandidata na vicero precteni (rozhodne bude repete, az Body vyjde v cestine).

I must admit that Bryson's A Short History of Nearly Everything was a slog for me, while Notes from a Small Island and A Walk in the Woods are among my favorite books, so perhaps I lean more toward his less science-focused works. The Body is a useful, approachable exploration with memorable stories (in particular, I feel like I will remember every astonishing story from the sleep chapter for a long time), but with less of the humor and lightness that some of his other books possess. Still, it's an accessible enough read that I can recommend it for my students, and it inspired me to take better care of my own body, so overall, that's a win.Thanks to the publishers and NetGalley for the digital ARC.

Fascinating, extensively researched guide to the human body and what makes it work. Filled with both facts and interesting historical and contemporary stories, this was a great read. It’s amazing to me how much we have no knowledge of - or guesses at best.As others have noted, not for the squeamish or those bothered by descriptions of sickness/disease/etc. I’m generally not a squeamish person, but one woman’s first-hand account of her 1810 mastectomy was extremely difficult to read.Unfortunately, the gender binary is very much enforced, especially in the chapter on reproductive organs. I wonder if this is a reflection of the comparatively small amount of scientific research on gender as a spectrum. I think it would have been good to at least mention the concept of being trans though.

I love Bill Bryson's writing - he's nothing if not thorough in his research and he always puts on a whimsical spin on things, regardless of the situation or subject. He has a wonderful outlook on things that I wish most people would adapt into their daily lives. Somehow, finding the humor in things that seem to not have a jot of it brings out the best in yourself and can calm you down.Anyways, that being said, there are facts galore in this look at what makes you you that may or may not distress you. Always entertaining and interesting despite being oft times gross and - well - grosser, Bill Bryson does not disappoint.The ending (which is about your ending) I found to be rather short. But life sometimes goes that way doesn't it.

I love Bill Bryson’s writing style and he did not disappoint in this book. It’s heavy on science, but in a good way with fun facts thrown in- like the surface area of our lungs (if they were spread out) would cover a tennis court. And we excrete millions of red blood cells a day. Wow!It’s a long book and sometimes I skimmed a bit of the history having to do with the researchers/discoverers of certain theories/drugs/genes/diseases/etc. but it was a very smooth blend of “here’s how this discovery in 1865 got us to where we are today”. Each chapter is a different part of the body and I feel much more educated on how our bodies work and the true miracle that we are!

*I was given an advanced copy of this title via NetGalley in exchange for an honest review*What can I say about Bill Bryson that hasn't already been said? He's a wonderful author with an amazingly articulate and witty voice. This particular book is jam-packed with facts, to the point where I had to read it one chapter at a time or my brain would get overwhelmed. It's a dense book and might be a slow read, but Bryson's voice gives it life in a way that other authors would lose my interest. He keeps it witty and engaging the entire time.

I find the human body to be so fascinating. As a medical professional, I had to undergo many years of learning about anatomy, physiology, and biochemistry to earn my degree. I loved learning about the science that makes us human, and I still do! Thus, The Body: A Guide for Occupants, was a real winner with me. Bryson has a way of relating information that makes reading nonfiction feel fun and engaging. I recommend this read for anyone who enjoys learning about science and humans and what makes us, us.

Needs more funny.The human body is amazing in two different ways: one, for what we know about it and how we came to know it; and two, what we don't know about it and the efforts we have made to get answers. This book needed to choose one or the other, or it needed to tell it all. As it is, it seems stuck in the middle. I wanted more stories and anecdotes. Bryson seems to have forgotten himself in the writing of this trying to get through the various workings of different body parts.

As an insecure know-nothing myself, I always appreciate it when a nonfiction book frequently repeats that the best that can be said about its topic is, “we just don’t know.”But seriously, Bryson’s pop-sci writing is always exemplary: succinct, informative, original, and touched with just enough humor and anecdote.

Amazing read, I learned new things about the human body. Educational, terrifying and entertaining all at the same time. I'm grateful how medical science has gotten us this far, and aghast at some of the included history and stories of what it took.
I liked it but, you know, there were some things I thought were missed and glossed over... but I'm an anatomist, so I don't expect a lay-reader to be bothered by any of that.
Bryson was his entertaining self and showed the right amount of awe for the wonders of the human body, but mostly it felt like he was going through the motions.
While this was highly interesting, I feel like it wasn't quite as charming as some of Bryson's other work. I would still thoroughly recommend this though!
This was easy to understand for someone who isn’t scientifically inclined. I need the hardcover ASAP!!! Most definitely re-reading this!
I finished this book and am now a licensed physician I think.
this was quite interesting at first, but then it just devolved into statistics about the US and the UK........ who's gonna tell him other countries exist 😳

Bill Bryson on oivallinen popularisoija ja kiinnostavien aiheiden penkoja, näin muutaman kirjan otoksella. Keho on tuttua Brysonia: kova faktapommitus, jossa käydään läpi ihmiskehon toimintaa alue kerrallaan ja siinä sivussa paljon lääketieteen historiaa.Se onkin melko värikästä tavaraa se, monia asioita on selvitetty nykynäkökulmasta varsin kammottavin menetelmin. Sanotaan nyt vaikka niin, että minulle ei kyllä tulisi mieleeni katetroida itseäni ihan kokeillakseni, pääseekö olkavarresta katetrilla verisuonia pitkin sydämeen. Tällaista kaikkea herkullisen kammottavaa ja groteskia pikkufaktaa kirja on pullollaan, joten herkimpiä varmasti ällöttää ja muut pääsevät nauttimaan mukavista puistatuksista.Bryson nostaa ansiokkaasti esiin monia unohdettuja tutkijoita, joiden työstä joku toinen on vienyt kunnian, tai muuten vain unohduksiin jääneitä hienoa työtä tehneitä lääketieteen edistäjiä. Toisaalta Bryson ei myöskään arkaile nostaa esiin lääketieteen heikkouksia, kuten sitä, että pitkään oli oikeastaan turvallisempaa pysytellä loitolla lääkäreistä, tai miten moderni lääketiede ei monessakaan kohdassa – etenkään Yhdysvalloissa – tuota käytettyä rahaa vastaan mitenkään erityisen hyviä tuloksia.Keho on oikein mainio kirja sekalaisen faktatiedon ystäville. Tämä on juuri sellainen kirja, jota lukemalla saa ärsytettyä kaikkia läheisiään: "hei, tiesittekö että..."

Z obawami sięgałam po "Ciało" po entuzjastycznych recenzjach, na które ciągle się natykałam. Książki popularno-naukowe z dziedziny medycyny to mój ulubiony podgatunek, liczyłam się z tym, że przeczytam zbiór ciekawostek w dużej mierze już mi znanych. Jednak Bill Bryson zaspokoił moją ciekawość, zawarł mnóstwo nowych dla mnie faktów i podał je w mój ulubiony sposób, czyli z tak zwanym tłem historycznym.To, co szczególnie cenne, to pokazanie jak postęp medycyny rodzi się w bólach i powstaje z pomyłek, jak wielu ma rodziców, często walczących o sławę i uznanie zupełnie nie po dżentelmeńsku. Bryson przytacza w książce wyniki najnowszych badań ale przyznaje też wielokrotnie, że pewne zjawiska nie są dobrze zbadane, funkcjonowanie organów bardziej skomplikowane, a w medycynie nadal jest więcej pytań niż odpowiedzi. Kończące "Ciało" fragmenty o zagrażającej pandemii nieprzyjemnie prorocze.Dla kogo?Fascynatów dr House'a i "Stulecia chirurgów" oraz zwykłych ciekawskich ludków.

“It was good while it lasted, wasn’t it?”[abstract de mi review completo]Me encanta la escritura de Bill Bryson. Por segunda vez me enseñó sobre temas de los que conozco poco y no sólo lo hace de una manera interesante y fácil de entender; sino también hace que el lector se de cuenta de lo que implica su humanidad. En este libro en específico, lo que implica que su maquinaria personal funcione de manera diaria las 24 horas de cada día. Buenísimo libro, todos lo deberían de leer para entender un poquito más sobre su propio cuerpo.PS: WOW todo lo que no sabemos sobre nuestro propio cuerpo, todavía hay demasiadas incógnitas que la medicina no ha podido contestar. Súper interesante!

final book for the O.W.L.s ✔️4.5How much do the resources that would be needed to build a human body cost? Why can we often not distinguish whether the bench is wet or cold? Why is it so difficult to tickle yourself?Really really interesting. Highly recommend.

Reading this book was like having your favourite lecturer having a talk about the extraordinary human body: the good and the bad, the medical advancements and drawbacks, the people behind the discoveries, while simultaneously delivering it with compassion and some tongue in cheek. The ending even made me a bit emotional. Slay.
Enjoyed this SO SO much!! I feel like a genius after reading, I now know everything there is to know about the body.

In his Bill Bryson breezy prose, the author has chosen the human body as the subject for this tome and because that’s just the way he writes, it’s eminently readable - and enjoyable. I found myself saying Huh or outright laughing on many occasions. For instance, “Ollivere gently incised and peeled back a sliver of skin about a millimeter thick from the arm of a cadaver. It was so thin as to be translucent. ‘That,’ he said, ‘is where all your skin color is. That’s all that race is —a sliver of epidermis.’” That got a Huh from me when I first read it and another Huh as I reread it just now.When he divulges information, he adds a example that we can relate to illustrate his point. For instance when he tells us that the region of the forebrain is associated with pleasure which grows to its largest size in teen years. “That is why the sensations you feel as a teenager are more intense than at any other time of life. But it also means that seeking pleasure is an occupational hazard for teenagers.” Instantly I thought of my son and the impulsive things he had done with bad outcomes. And I had to read that part out loud to my husband. In fact, I had to read out loud to him on several occasions. I’m sure he’s glad I’ve finished the book.There are factoids scattered though the chapters, like how MSG got it’s bad reputation. We read about the rise in diabetes throughout the world which probably comes as a surprise to no one. But who knew that that type I diabetes in Finland has risen 550 percent since 1950 and continues to rise almost every where else at a rate of 3-5 percent. No one knows why. Huh!Or that people who had their tonsils removed while young have a 55% great chance of having a heart attack in later life. Really?!!I thoroughly enjoyed this book, as I do all of Bryson’s books, and if you’re wondering how a book on the human body could be engaging, take my word for it. It is.

Bill Bryson, through extensive reading, has compiled a book all about the body. He outlines the history of acquiring knowledge from the most conceivable moment up to the present day, citing the discoveries of various parts of the body when they occurred and by whom. Myths are dispelled such as taking vitamin C will help get rid of a cold or that we need to drink eight glasses of water a day. He discusses practices to help an individual live a healthy, quality of life such as couch potatoes (those sitting six or more hours a day) can benefit by walking around during commercials to burn 180 calories an hour or just standing to burn 107 calories an hour. Recommendations by the World Health Organization such as the daily recommendation for sugar intake is a maximum of five teaspoons are also presented. A muliitude of diseases have come and gone, only to replaced by another disease such as the Heartland virus in 2018. Now there is the Coronavirus which is new since the publication of The Body. How operations have evolved over the years with some horrendous descriptions of earlier operations such as the mastectomy of Fanny Burney, an English novelist, in 1810. Bryson reiterates Daniel E. Lieberman, professor of human evolutionary biology at Harvard: belief that 70 percent of the diseases that kill us could easily be preventable if we would just live sensibly

Reading through many of the GR and literary journal reviews, a high percentage of readers like relating the stats from this latest offering from Bill Bryson. Several copies of, "the flight attendant who survived a fall of 33,000 ft, cushioned by fir trees; the Spanish diver who held his breath for 24 minutes." Bet you didn't know this one: a study of 60 people’s belly buttons found 2,368 species of bacteria, 1,458 of them “unknown to science.”Okay. Fun facts.My takeaway from this (I listened to the CD audiobook edition, wryly narrated by Bryson) is yes, the sheer beauty of our bodies, the wonderful safeguards, fail-safes that our being transmit to us...and the mind-body connection. Sometimes those transmissions are outright red neon warnings, such as, "not one more bite...I'm full!"So much of our healthcare culture is waiting for the next miracle drug. Funding the latest screening device or test. Traveling long distances to the highest rated and marketed care facility. Then, who pays for all this?Yet, our bodies, our minds, our innate feelings counsel and guide us every moment. Bryson lets this mantra of self knowledge, self direction, bubble up and float through his book. We all know the placebo effect. It's in here. People reported feeling better after taking a placebo, even after being told beforehand, it's a placebo.Our bodies crave good health. Our bodies are designed and built to move. That same body will tell the occupant when to rest. How and when to nourish. How to educate the mind to detect and then act on these feelings better. The lessons are repeated until learned. Happy, sharing people live, as an average, longer.We just have to listen.

I love Bill Bryson! I have read every book he's written (even his dictionary! Seriously!) I love the most his books on giant single subjects and yet I'm also always astonished when he comes up with a new area for those. The Body may be his best yet.As always, it's utterly filled with trivia, bizarre fact, and anyone with just a passing understanding of anatomy and medicine will find something fascinating every few minutes. Did you know that if all your DNA was made into a single strand and stretched out end to end, it was stretch past Pluto and out of the solar system? Did you know that most stutterers are left-handed? And that stuttering is much worse in those who are left-handed but were forced to learn to write right-handed? Did you know that we get 2-5 cancer cells every single day of our lives, which our immune systems get rid of? And that kissing is a surprisingly bad way to spread a cold? My husband doesn't have any idea how lucky he is that I listened to this book while I was out of town and he was spared a massive amount of gasping and me telling him interesting things endlessly (he still got a few). And you need to have no prior knowledge or interest in the subject at all--I nearly failed my high school biology class.Mr. Bryson narrates the book himself, and I know some people find him an annoying narrator, but I do not at all. He has developed a bit of a British accent and I find him charming. It's the best of both worlds where he sounds fancy and slightly foreign but he doesn't pronounce words like "laboratory" in that bizarre British way.I found the book utterly delightful, completely fascinating, and I wish it had been twice as long.

I like Bill Bryson. I read and enjoyed:" A short walk" & "A sunburned country", but I lost my patience with "A short history of nearly everything". I blame myself for that. What was I expecting? With this latest book, I have to say, it is not a book to read all the way through. It's probably the only book I'll ever recommend for those of you who like to have reading material accessible in the bathroom. You could read it in limited amounts of time and never run out of reading material or patience. It's really fascinating when taken in little bits at a time. For example did you know that if your lungs were stretched out and flattened they would cover a tennis court? And so on. But you can see why you wouldn't want to sit down and read it from start to finish or worse, listen to your partner reading it aloud to you in bed before you fall asleep which I guarantee you will not be long. For example, did you know that in 2018, a professor at Oxford found that low-dose aspirin is not effective at all in reducing cardiac or cancer risk in anyone weighing 154 pounds or more--but it does still post a serious risk of internal bleeding.etc.,etc.,etc. All good information in low doses. No pun intended.

Bill Bryson is one of my absolute favorite authors, so I was so excited to receive an advance copy of this book to read! If you enjoyed his previous books At Home and A Short History of Nearly Everything, then you'll also like this one. It's basically a fascinating, witty, and concise overview of the different systems that make up the human body, along with the diseases, viruses, etc. that plague us. As with all Bryson books, I loved his signature wit and the plethora of little known, captivating facts he includes. In fact, there were times when Bryson devoted only a single sentence to a particular fact, such as some unbelievable brain disorders (being convinced you're dead when you're really alive, being blind but sure you can see, etc.) that I wished he would have expanded on. Perhaps part of Bryon's brilliance, however, is in engaging the reader's curiosity and giving us plenty to ponder and research ourselves once the book is over. I know whenever I finish one of his books that I'm going to have a list of further reading and topics for discovery thanks to all the irresistible tidbits he mentions.

I enjoyed reading this book just as I have all of the Bryson books I have read. He has an easy, amusing writing style that always makes for pleasurable reading. There are many interesting facts in this book, but because I have read so many medical/disease/health care type books, there were also many things I had read before and already knew. The chapters on the brain and sleep were overviews for me since I have read a number of books on both subjects and the chapters in this book are rather short given the subject matter, but this book is attempting to cover all of the human body and so the chapters are necessarily short. The chapters on skin and hair, the heart and blood, and the skeleton are fascinating. This book is an interesting summary of most everything about our human bodies and is well worth reading. It is sprinkled with interesting anecdotes about various famous doctors, scientists, and patients that add greatly to the book as it documents the history of medical discovery about the human body and the advancement of that knowledge.

Audio book.I think I have enjoyed every Bill Bryson book I've ever read or listened to, and that is the majority of his books. This one focuses upon the human body and does not shy away from any area. The information is, as always, exacting and delivered in such a way that understanding is guaranteed. You'll also be charmed by the little asides, stories, and interviews. The last section on cancer and death was excellent, if a somewhat depressing end to the book (I don't think it could have been avoided, much like death itself), and there was an air of reassurance about it.Some of the worst information you discover along the way is the awfulness of US healthcare statistics, and the awfulness of UK healthcare statistics (esp cancer survival) - for two very wealthy countries, something seriously needs to be change!Anyway, if you can cope with that, this book is an incredible read (listen) and I recommend it to everyone!

I loved everything about this book. But most of all, every time I read it, I learned something new. As much as it seems like we already know our own bodies, there is so much that I had no idea about.Overall, this book favors breath over depth, which is fine. There are lots of other great books out there to dive into topics like microbiology of the stomach or aging or genetics, but this book did a great job of giving a high-level view while giving just enough detail to understand it without becoming overly complex or boring. And, on top of that, the author was super funny and made it enjoyable to learn about some topics that were difficult, like aging, death, and dementia.I'm super excited to read this book again in the future, and this book also referred me to many other books that I hadn't heard of before that I'll probably check out next.This book is probably my favorite of all the books I've read this year.

Well, Bill Bryson has done it again! This book moves into my top-ten list and I'd easily give it a higher than 5-star rating. Highly recommended!So why the superb rating? First, I enjoyed it to the point where I'd reread it sometime soon. Bryson's writing style is relaxed, humorous, and extremely easy to follow. Second, I learned a LOT, and his tendency to explore immensely interesting bunny trails contributes mightily to the enjoyment. He never takes himself too seriously. I feel like he is a "reader's author". In other words, he makes great effort to make his books page-turners for the average reader like me.I won't summarize the book, you can get that from the jacket. Just be prepared to laugh while you learn an amazing amount - read "The Body" by Bill Bryson.

Being a Bill Bryson fan I knew this could only be good, and indeed I was not disappointed. It is a very thourough summary of what happens in our bodies, with a lot of focus on what can go wrong. As usual some science history as well, and I have learned a lot of new things.But I have mainly learned that there is a lot that we don't know yet about how our body really works, and that we are a wonder of science. Also, it appears that being born and living in Europe has a lot of benefits when compared with living in the US. Good to know!I recommend it to everyone that likes science and science's history, people who like to know more and enjoy fun trivia. However, beware, if you have a tendencie towards hypocondria, nothing good will come from reading this. You will itch all over.

Bill Bryson is a natural and gifted teacher. I've said that before in at least one review, but it is worth saying again. He is better known for his humorous travel books but when he decides to cover a subject, I pay attention. In this case, he provides a class in physiology that is better and more understandable than anything I've read elsewhere. The information he is providing is up to date with everything I've seen recently and also what I've heard from my doctor. The big bonus was that I listened to an unabridged audiobook production and Bill Bryson read it. Unlike many authors, he is a very good narrator. I got the print book from my library to read over a few sections that I wanted to review. I actually would buy this as a reference book if my library didn't already own it.

In Bill Bryson's The Body, he talks about all aspects of the human body, literally from head to toe. He begins at the head, goes into the brain, the heart, the lungs, as well as almost every single major organ and aspect of our bodies. While this sounds like it can be an extremely dull topic, Bryson spices up the subject matter with interesting anecdotes, entertaining facts and just a relatability that can make anyone like and enjoy this book. Every chapter is equally entertaining and engaging. I thought this was a book that people should really try to read to learn more about what makes you you.

Ever since reading “Little Dribbling,” I have been watching for a new book from Bill Bryson. He’s known best for his science-related books, of course, so he is sure to please all of his fans with this latest offering. And what an offering it is! An homage to the great gift that is the human body, this narrative is filled with all of the facts – both fun and serious – you need to truly respect what The Body does for us. Between Bill Bryson and Malcom Gladwell, I am a happy literary-science camper. Got more? Bring it on!I met this book at Auntie's Bookstore in Spokane, WA

As someone who is in the closing stages of a degree on the Healthcare Sciences, I was curious to see how far Bryson would go in to the depth of the subject as he did not appear to have a clinical background. The answer is that he handled the level of detail very well, he went into complex detail but didn't drown the reader. I found it engaging and very interesting and not a re-hash of standard quotes.I would thoroughly recommend this book, even to experts. It is well written and moves along very nicely.

As with all Bill Bryson books, this was extremely fascinating.I did like that this book was a bit shorter and more focused on topic than the usual.With some of his other books, it sometimes drifts so far that you are not quite sure what your are listening to.Not worth digging into all the topics covered by the book.If you are even vaguely into Bill Bryson or Biology or simply like to know about a lot of things, this book is for you. I'd definitely recommend this one above some of the others I've done.

The Body: A Guide for Occupants (2019) by Bill Bryson is an entertaining, informative book that takes the reader on a tour of our bodies.The Body is really a lot of fun and the descriptions of skin, hair, stomachs, food, brains, bones, cancer, DNA and everything else and the people who discovered how they work and what makes them go wrong is really well done. There are just so many interesting anecdotes and facts and they really are delivered well.The Body is a highly enjoyable and is very much worth a read.

As usual for Bryson this brims with interesting facts and stories as we explore different systems and areas of the human body. Based on my previous reading on various of these areas some subjects are oversimplified and others overemphasized to an extent to give the reader a slightly skewed idea of the concept at hand. On the whole though this is a valuable work which dispels many common myths and educates readers on things they may not even have known they were missing.
