A good book. Well researched and delivered in an interesting way. I thoroughly enjoyed it. Knew a lot of things mentioned in the book already but also learned quite a few new, useful facts about our bodies, lifestyle, illnesses, expectations ...Really liked little stories about discovery and development of Streptomycin, a very interesting story about Salmonella and so on. Liked B. Bryson's comments on various issues and his sense for humour. Well written popular science, always interesting cos it is all about us, well presented and not boring at all.

I have recently read "Stiff: The Curious Lives of Human Cadavers" by Mary Roach which also explores the mysteries of human body. Although it talked about human body from different perspective, I found both "The Body" and "Stiff" similarly fascinating. How is it that the most familiar thing to ourselves be such an enigmatic paradox. There will be many more years until we finally discover the true potential and solve the human body puzzle or we may never be able to. Regardless, Bill Bryson tried to explain this wonder in a simple and interesting way. Great book.

I would highly recommend this book to a friend. I had just finished "A Short History Of Nearly Everything" by Bill Bryson before reading this book. The structure of this book is similar to that one, if not the same. This book is easy to comprehend and very informative. I particularly liked the chapter that focused on nutrition. Bill Bryson has become one of my favorite authors and I look forward to reading more of his books in the future.

If only Bill Bryson would have written all of my textbooks. The Body took me a little while to read, but it’s long and I kept returning to re-read nuggets I wanted to remember. Everything Bill writes is thorough and full of facts you wished you could memorize for daily conversation and dinner parties. Another win for Bill Bryson as I work my way through his catalogue.

Incredible! The human body AND this book. A perfect combination of facts, history, future outlooks and humor. You know it’s a good book when you keep quoting little facts to anyone who will listen.My favorite quote? “On one hand, sperm are heroic...the only cells designed to leave our body and explore other worlds.But on the other hand, they are blundering idiots.”

A fun museum tour of the body.The author goes section by section telling you what happens in every part of your body, how our understanding of the same was developed and the challenges we see today. This is accompanied by a barrage of trivia and intriguing stories. Overall a fun read (even if I may remember very little of what I read)

Bill Bryson faz livros que são a epítome do puro prazer da leitura. Neste, onde nos inunda de factos, muitos deles pouco conhecidos, sobre a nossa morada primordial, mostra a sua imagem de marca: profunda investigação do tema; foco nos aspetos menos conhecidos e nas ideias erradas que se instalam na cultura popular.5*

Bryson presents, chapter-by-chapter, an introduction to what each part of the human body does. I found this absolutely fascinating and thoroughly informative. It does make you wonder though what on earth went through some men's minds when they began some of their strange experiments.

Clever little book, this one; but perhaps a little light on the humor and a little shallow on the subject? I might appreciate more of Bryson’s narrative gifts here, but instead we get more Bryson-as-reporter or tour guide.

I am not even a science-y person, and this was FASCINATING. I think if you are a science person, you would especially love it, but it's interesting for anyone! Bryson does such a good job distilling complicated things into layman's terms, and he narrates the audio himself.

Though I am familiar with Bryson’s travelogues, this is the first time I read something by him outside that genre. Nevertheless, I was fascinated, and at times repulsed, by the facts he chose to include about our human body, it’s complex systems, and fascinating parts.
Great info along with Bryson’s dry wit.
"You'll laugh; you'll cry. You'll hurl."
So interesting. Anecdotes were amazing.So much research and statistics to review.Really made me think!
This audiobook passed in a fascinating blur of facts, none of which I will be able to recall.
Pues si. Cinco estrellas. Como siempre una lección sobre un todo, bien estructurada y salpicada de anécdotas y datos de lo más curiosos...
Umm okay I liked reading about skin and sleeping but I skimmed through most of the book. I wasn't expecting total biology lessons but okay
I just have one word for this book: FASCINATING. So glad I was brave enough to dive in and read it!

Writing a popular science book that's understandable and fun for the lay(wo)man is one thing, but to make it fun and worth listening to for someone who does know the minutia of the topic is another. I've spent a lot of time and money learning and forgetting about the intricacies of the human body: sitting through hours of lectures; poring over pages of facts, figures, diagrams; and seeing it off the page as well. For me, this book could have ended up being a more watered down slightly less pedantic review book - and that would have probably bored me to death. However, The Body: A Guide for Occupants isn't written by someone trying to teach "plebes" about their field, it isn't written by a science writer at all. Bill MoFo Bryson is the author of this book, and if anyone could find a way to make something interesting to everyone regardless of background, it's him. I may be biased, several of Bill Bryson's books rank among my favorite books of all time (A Walk in the Woods: Rediscovering America on the Appalachian Trail, and I'm a Stranger Here Myself: Notes on Returning to America After Twenty Years Away in particular) so perhaps I'm just predisposed to liking the work he puts out. While there is a very basic rundown of the different parts of the body, their functions, and other related topics (conversations on public health, microbiology, epidemiology, etc...) there's also a lot of trivia, history, anecdotes that help everyone understand that we really know very little about the human body - but we worked hard to get there.The book is written in Bryson's characteristic fun and light manner, but it's full of information presented in a way that makes it feel that he's just as overjoyed to learn about each tidbit as you should be reading it. It's joyful education, even more so when listening to the audiobook which he reads. Listening to an emotive person joyfully explaining the different parts and functions of the brain is a completely different experience from listening to a droning soporific professor. I can't really speak for how info-dumpy it may be, a lot of it is just refreshing my memory of things I know followed by interesting bits of trivia or history that I either didn't remember or didn't learn. Honestly, the non-science parts were more interesting to me because it's fascinating to see what parts of history gets left behind. There's a lot of backstabbing in the research and academic world, that's for sure.I do wonder if he wishes that the book was released next year, because while his chapter on the pandemic that would bring our society to it's knees was pretty spot on, it would have definitely been different knowing what we know now. Though all the experts he interviewed were pretty accurate on the characteristics of a virus that could cause a pandemic, and how unprepared the world would be for it. People keep asking the question "who could have known?!", well, apparently a lot of people - enough that Bill Bryson has a whole chapter on it before the pandemic started.This is a fun book, and well narrated by Bryson. This is the perfect light but informative non-fiction book to listen to while walking the dog.

*4.5*Това не е книга, това е мини енциклопедия или, както и самото подзаглавие си казва - това си е наръчник. Българското издание допринася още повече за това усещане - голям формат, твърди масивни корици и хубави плътни страници. Последните 20 страници са пълни с източници, така че дори само това трябва да ви е достатъчно, че да вземете "Тялото" на сериозно. Получих книгата като подарък за миналата Коледа и ми отне цяла година да я прочета. Не искам да си представям колко време е прекарал Бил Брайсън в написването ѝ. Но пък напълно си е заслужавало!Факт е, че 400 страници са крайно недостатъчни, за да се разгледа тялото в цялата му същност, но пък се оказва, че те са съвсем подходящ размер, за да се положи основата за неговото изучаване. В книгата ще намерите по една глава з�� всяка система в човешкото тяло и ще научите най-важното за нея. В допълнение има много интересни и любопитни факти, както и историята на не един учен или лекар, спомогнали за това да достигнем до днешните ни медицински познания. За по-запознатите от вас, вероятно голяма част от информацията в "Тялото" няма да е нова, но пък си мисля, че повечето хора не познават собствените си тела чак толкова добре, че да намерят книгата за ненужна. Тя е от онези четива, към които ще може да се допитвате с години напред или ако не друго, то поне да си припомняте това-онова. Най-хуабвото в нея обаче е, че е написана на много достъпен и лесно разбираем език, а личните истории, разказани вътре, са много увлекателни и остават своя ярък отпечатък. Друг огромен плюс е, че авторът не се страхува да каже, че учените все още нямат отговор на много въпроси, както и да покаже тъмната страна на науката и нейните грешки през годината. Да, това може би не е най-полезният подход по време на световна пандемия, но в крайна сметка е важно да знаем истината за миналото и да се учим от него, вместо да се преструваме, че такива неща не са се случвали. Четейки, човек започва лека-полека да изпитва страхопочитание към собственото си тяло. От една страна неговите сложни, но изключително стиковани процеси са изумителни. Невероятно е как нещо подобно може да съществува и да се развива съвсем само. Невероятно е и колко рядко всъщност дава на късо. В този ред на мисли, ако сте по-параноични или си падате малко хипохондрици, може би е по-добре да не четете "Тялото" - знанието колко много неща могат да се объркат във всеки един момент ще ви побърка.За единствен недостатък на книгата бих посочила липсата на изображения. Като човек, който запомня най-лесно чрез образи, картинки и графики, усетих тяхното отсъствие още в самото начало. Дори си позволих да нарисувам по нещо в празните пространства около текста в името на това да разбера написаното по-добре. Сигурна съм, че цветните изображения биха вдигнали себестойността на книгата, но все пак щеше да си заслужава и да я направи още по-ценна.

Did you know you have a meter of DNA packed into every cell? That scientists don't know exactly how smell works, and that there is a smell disorder where one only smells shit? That in some cases it's better to be anemic (low on blood) than to get a blood transfusion? That the United States is 4% of the world's population, and uses 80% of its opioids? These, and many more fun body and medical facts, can be yours in this travelogue-esque exploration of the human body and many of its subsystems. I was not wild about most of the sections of food and metabolism as author Gary Taubes as me thoroughly convinced that 1) the calories-in, calories-out model of metabolism is flawed, and 2) that dietary fats have little to no impact on heart disease. Bryson didn't have enough room to explore this fully, so it made me wonder what else he glossed over or over-simplified in writing this book. Wobbled between 3 and 4 stars. There is some great, enjoyable, interesting, funny stuff in here, but I typically enjoy depth over breadth. Other folks would enjoy this much more than me!

Bill Bryson has made quite the career out of funny, informative, light reading books and *The Body* is no exception. Each chapter covers some portion of the human body, like discussions about blood, brain, nerves, sex organs, death and cancer. Here are a few tidbits of info for your perusal:+ If you blew [a virus] up to the size of a tennis ball, a human would be five hundred miles high. A bacterium on the same scale would be about the size of a beach ball.+ researchers infected the metal door handle to an office building and found it took only about four hours for the “virus” to spread through the entire building, infecting over half of employees and turning up on virtually every shared device like photocopiers and coffee machines.+ Giraffes, oddly, sometimes have gallbladders and sometimes don’t.+ To power our forward motion, we have a distinctively gigantic muscle in our buttocks, the gluteus maximus, and an Achilles tendon, something no ape has.+ If you are deprived of it for long enough, you will die—though what exactly it is that kills you from lack of sleep is a mystery, too.+ The prostate, it might be said, produces seminal fluid throughout a man’s adulthood and anxiety in his later years.+ It has been suggested, in fact, that if all men lived long enough, they would all get prostate cancer.+ That’s why you are constantly told to eat more fiber: because it keeps your gut microbes happy and at the same time, for reasons not well understood, reduces the risk of heart disease, diabetes, bowel cancer, and indeed death of all types.But the most amazing one to me was in the chapter on the brain. In discussing how long it takes an image to get from your eye to the brain (about a fifth of a second) :+ To help us deal better with this fractional lag, the brain does a truly extraordinary thing: it continuously forecasts what the world will be like a fifth of a second from now, and that is what it gives us as the present.Mind blowing. It was also amazing just how little we still know about the body, especially the "Whys". My wife is probably glad I am finally finished reading the book so I will stop interrupting her reading by narrating another wild fact from the book!My two biggest take aways from the book are that while there are indeed plenty of disagreements about what we need and don't need, the scientific community is solidly behind the need for both exercise and, believe it or not, fiber. Exercise continually showed up in the book, as it reduces the odds of everything from cancer to Alzheimer's. And while there might be some disagreement on how much of both exercise and fiber, both are essential to a healthy life. As one of fibers biggest boosters (again, much to my wife's chagrin), I felt vindicated!So while this isn't any kind of text book, it sure is an informative and interesting read. You will learn a lot of things you just didn't know before. And he also name drops a lot of other books for more in depth study, which I have added to my Want To Read list, like Clean: The New Science of Skin and the Beauty of Doing Less, Bonk: The Curious Coupling of Science and Sex and Microcosm: E. Coli and the New Science of Life. Gotta get to reading!

Super easy and comprehensive read. My favorite quote from this was "Until further notice, I am alive". Every chapter I learned something new and unexpected like how the brain can hold as much information as the entire digital library or how the entire global supply of penicillin to this day originates from bacteria found on a single cantaloupe from the middle of America. From a body mechanics standpoint, it is amazing how the body has adapted to be incredibly efficient at what it does. Compared to machine design, the body is operating with a hammer and chisel at times yet blows anything human design can achieve out of the water. It is crazy how far our knowledge of the body has progressed since the seemingly ridiculous experiments that earlier generations carried out. It is also crazy how little our knowledge of the body has progressed since the seemingly ridiculous experiments that earlier generations carried out. The last few chapters are difficult to get through as they deal with disease, death, how terrible health care can be, but gave me so much respect for life and the amazing obstacles that our bodies overcome behind the scenes. This book has most definitely made me a more informed occupant of the body.

Head to toe - literally. So much recently discovered information. We really are still learning. Costa Ricans have only about one-fifth the personal wealth of Americans, and have poorer health care, but live longer. Moreover, people in one of the poorest regions of Costa Rica, the Nicoya Peninsula, live longest of all, even though they have much higher rates of obesity and hypertension. The also have longer telomeres.The theory is that they benefit from closer social bonds and family relationships. Curiously, it was found that if they live alone or don't see a child at least one a week, the telomere length advantage vanishes. It is an extraordinary fact that having good and loving relationships physically alters your DNA. Conversely, a 2010 study found, not having such relationships doubles your risk of dying from any cause.I bought a hard copy for reference, but listened to Bryson read this audio version.

Never met a BB book I didn’t like, and this one is no different. Highly informative and entertaining. Lots of factoids about the various parts of the human body, combined with historical anecdote, done in Bryson style.There are a few dabs of cognitive dissonance scattered through the book, as expected from anything to do with medicine or physiology. More than once my bullshit meter gave a twitch. But in general it was a great read.I noted that although the chapter on pain includes a little missive on opioids, but the chapter on blood chemistry doesn’t have an equivalent criticism of statins.The section on infectious diseases was particularly interesting and ironic, given that this book was published in 2019.And by the way, my edition was an audiobook, read by the author himself. The very last line was certainly worth waiting for.

Bryson's an accomplished storyteller, and so can make entertaining a survey of parts of the human body, and the progress of medical science toward vaguely understanding them.I won't rate it on the science, since it's been a while since I made any study of it. It's interesting how facts morph and accepted truths change. MSG, for instance, has never been proven to be bad for anyone (at normal rates of consumption), but I still see proud 'no MSG' labels on food.And nothing could be better as a negative advertisement for time travel (to the past) than a description of a breast cancer operation pre the use the anaesthetic.Also notable that this was published a few years before the COVID-19 pandemic, and it's eerie listening to the discourse on successful diseases being the ones with the less formidible mortality rates, since the scarier the disease is, the more seriously people will treat it, and the harder it is to spread.

Phenomenal. 1. The author does not believe in God. That is so so sad to believe that the human body functions as it does by chance.2. As a Christian, I see the beauty behind the intelligent design. The human body is magnificent. God is to be praised for this.3. The author describes the hundreds of thousands of dangers out there to the human body stating that it is a miracle that we haven’t been affected by them. I see the providential hand as the cause of this miracle protecting us. What a comfort to know that none of these potential dangers has the potential to harm human bodies by chance. 4. It was interesting, informative, and well written. Plus there is still so much scientists do not know about the human body. 5. I finished this book feeling intrigued and in awe of the human body and it’s Creator.

Bill Bryson didn’t write this book to make people worship God, but I couldn’t help it. As he described our amazing bodies, I couldn’t help but think how intricately and wonderfully we are designed. This book is full of useful-only-on-Jeopardy!-truly-mind-blowing facts (The length of one person’s blood vessels would wrap around Earth 2.5 times!) I think this book could be summarized by saying: Our bodies are unbelievable, and humans know way less about them than we’d like to admit. Unsurprisingly there’s a fair amount of talk of evolution, and some disappointing views about the economic cost of taking care of the elderly, but this book is still very much worth the read for the sheer awe it inspires.

Bill Bryson is one of the best nonfiction writers I have encountered. His language is incredibly crisp and the research he employs must be staggering. Bryson deftly devours a massive quantity of information and reports it in a way that demonstrates comprehension filled with dry humor and interesting little facts that pique the mind. The Body is an excellent book and one I would recommend to those with any sort of inquiring mind and even for those who seldom read nonfiction. This is a book you could easily work on over a longer time and pick it up to read after long intervals without losing reading steam.

This book gave me a newfound respect for my body and everything it does to keep me alive - as well as a newfound anxious dread pertaining to all the ways I can apparently die. Did you know 50% of healthy people can suffer a heart attack for seemingly no reason at all? Do I even count as a healthy person? Who knows what’s actually going on inside my cells... Scary stuff.If you lean towards hypochondria, don’t read this. Although in some ways fascinating, a detailed list of everything that can randomly and unavoidably kill you doesn’t make for light reading. I enjoyed it and got through it quickly, but once I was done I felt the need to go get a CAT scan, just in case.

What strikes me most is how much we still don’t know (especially the answer to why anything does what it does) and how many important discoveries were made by complete accident and the amount of egoism and betrayal are behind a lot of scientific research. I’m grateful my body works as well as it does considering and that I haven’t been the test subject of any medical research, particularly that took place before the 21st century.

The book is quite basic and easy to read. The author focuses on anecdotes from the history of medicine and biology as much as he tries to avoid going into technical depth. It also feels like the author is talking to an average white, male, young, American throughout the book; a global perspective on health is lacking. Would not recommend this book to other readers. Here is one-line summary: Watch what you eat and lead an active life.

A fascinating read about each major component of our bodies, the history of such discoveries, and the medical interventions that helped and hurt over the centuries. I enjoyed this, particularly the later chapters that talked about the risk of the flu (this was published just before the pandemic so it’s really interesting how respiratory illness is discussed) and about death and dying/the US’s massive investments in the medical industry compared to other nations more effective less expensive health care systems.

Beth says:Who knew that a detailed account of the human body would be so fascinating? Bill Bryson brings humor to a subject that may seem dry and scientific. He takes us through a step-by-step tour of every part of the human body with so many unusual facts and anecdotes. While you probably won’t remember all the endless tidbits about each part, you will be left with a new appreciation for what the body does. I listened to the audiobook version and it kept me entertained throughout. Read by the author, he has a dry sense of humor enhanced by some of his Britishisms.

This book is exactly as advertised: a guide for occupants. I am doing a PhD in bioinformatics and computational biology, but I didn’t know the majority of what was discussed in this book. I loved learning about everything and listening to Bill Bryson reading it himself was a great experience.It was so great that it was almost trivial. I really don’t know how else to express my feelings.

Īpaši šobrīd, kad VISIEM ir skaļš viedoklis, visaptverošas zināšanas un, protams, BrāļaKolēģaMāsaDaktere man teica sindroms, vērts atsvaidzināt zināšanas vai tās izveidot par savu ķermeni. Dette er i utgangspunktet en veldig informativ bok, men med (per nå) 3 års legeutdanning er jeg allerede informert om mye av det forfatteren ønsker å formidle. Likevel koste jeg meg med boken. For ufaglærte anbefales den hvis man er interessert i å få en viss oversikt av kroppen.

I absolutely loved reading this book. I also loved recognising various things that I’ve already learned in university, and others that I didn’t know or just didn’t understand that well.
Місцями не вистачало деталей та пояснень, наче автор почав про щось розповідати і забув. І якби книжка була написана хоча б на рік пізніше, автору не довелось лякати нас «можливою» пандемією :)
A very approachable AP bio refresher.

I like this author a lot and his wry sense of humor. However, it was hard to inject humor in a book like this that was mostly scientific. That aside, the book is well written and polished. Mostly the book had information we already knew, or didn't need to know. A strong conclusion at the ending, but one we already knew. So, this book is a small work of art that we probably don't need to read.

So great! Like many (if not all) of Bryson’s books, this is such fun to read. You can hear his wry wit through the words, making it feel like a funny friend is educating you with all these incredible facts about the human body!

This is a biology book like no other you have ever read. It is a serious book that is packed with information, much of it highly scientific, but it is always readable and understandable. And here's the secret sauce that makes it so much fun to read: It is often irreverent, frequently hilarious, and repeatedly snarky. Translation: It's fun to read!Prodigiously researched and written by travel writer Bill Bryson, this is a deep dive for laypeople (no medical degree needed) into mysteries of the human body from head to toe. This is a book about you! Chapters cover everything from the brain to the guts to the nerves. You'll learn not only how our various pieces and parts work, but also what happens when things go wrong. But it's not just boring fact after boring fact after boring fact. For example, in the chapter on skin, the body's largest organ, you'll find out such fascinating revelations as:• When you touch something, your brain not only tells you *how* something feels, but also how it *ought* to feel, which is why a lover's caress induces a sigh and the same touch by a creepy stranger could make you shudder.• Sweating is activated by the release of adrenaline, which is why you break into a sweat when you're stressed.Oh, and the very accurate biological description of sperm in chapter 18, "In the Beginning: Conception and Birth" is so funny I laughed out loud. Meanwhile, other parts are only for the strong of stomach, such as the description of what is likely the most extraordinary story on record of appendectomy survival and a recounting by the patient herself in a letter to her sister of the first mastectomy, performed in 1810 without anesthesia.Why read a book about your body? Not only is it interesting to learn what makes us tick, as well as sick, but also it could help you to live a healthier and longer life. Understanding how your body works can make you appreciate and care for it better instead of taking it for granted.It's not often that a nonfiction book can be described as witty, amusing, and highly entertaining, but that's exactly what this is.
Informative and structured well.

a fun and easy read that left me feeling more educated on the body, mostly its fascinating how little we actually know about the skin&bone costumes that we wear around each day, i also feel loaded up with fun facts for dinner parties and game nights, thanks bill bryson
Incredible audiobook.
Bill Bryson makes anything he writes about fascinating! Highly recommended.

Really enjoyed this, an accessible, easy to understand account of interesting facts, comparisons and anecdotes. Perfect for someone not especially scientifically inclined. Learned a lot! Took a while to get through though.

A comprehensive brush up on biology lessons, especially for last benchers who yawned away and perked up only with the mention of the words ‘reproductive organs’. If you are nodding in agreement, this book is written for ‘US’. Being a fact rammed book with rib tickling trivia for some part, it is hard to retain facts but peppers your curiosity to know more. A well researched, neatly put together, easy-to-binge-read book on such a complicated subject - the inner workings of a human being. If you are a ‘being human’ with human tendencies, read this. If you are a ‘human being’ with animal tendencies, read them anyway. It will be useful one day.
loved.

The book is worth reading for anyone curious about how the body works; what elevates it to 4.5 stars are the stories of discoveries and highlighting the forgotten heroes because of whom we live longer and healthier lives.

This book is so fun to read. I would read sections here and there and learned so many fun facts that I will probably forget in a couple weeks, but for now I feel full of interesting information ab0ut the human body. My favorite chapters were about sleep and the gut.

Review title: Be glad you're aliveBruce Springsteen is indeed right: it ain't no sin to be glad you're alive, an emotion you'll feel after reading about the body through Bill Bryson's pen. It's a marvelous machine--no, far better actually, Bryson realizes and writes: no machine made by man has yet had (and likely never will) the complexity, strength, flexibility, endurance, and intelligence of the human body. It's a good place to live. Bryson has written about pretty much everything from hiking the Appalachian Trail to living in England to--well, everything (A Short History of Everything was the first of his books I read), always with a sense of humor and curiosity about the world around him. He is an American transplant to the UK where he met his wife and they have spent most of their married years, but he retains an American view of the world (yes there is one, identifiable by passers-by on the street even without hearing the accent, a British coworker and friend assures me) and the body even as he interviews experts and includes examples from both countries. As Bryson tours around and through the body chapter by chapter it is astonishing how much is unique about humans from other members of the animal kingdom, how intricately things fit together and work in the only way they possibly could, and how little we know about how and why the body and its parts work. Bryson describes these intricate mechanics, chemistry, and physics as the end result of genetic mutation or environmental adaptation and often gently deflects away theories of intelligent design, even when the statistical probability of evolution approaches impossibly small numbers. This isn't a medical textbook or how-to guide to personal health and body maintenance. It is just a fun exercise in curiosity about the shell our minds, souls, and lives occupy, and the scientists and medical doctors and experimenters who have poked and prodded it through the centuries. The usual suspects are in play (da Vinci, Harvey, Salk) but leave it to Bryson to highlight the often oddball men and women who haven't been given the credit they deserve. It is astonishing how little was known two centuries ago, last century, even last decade and how wrong prevailing theories and treatments were then; it raises the question of how astonishing current medical practices will appear to our grandchildren just a few decades hence. It was also written and published before the corona virus pandemic exploded, so it does not specifically address the virus, although he does write about why pharmaceutical companies are investing less and less time and money in research and development of drugs to treat these new environmental risks; as a consequence, Bryson concludes prophetically, "In the event of a really catastrophic epidemic--one that killed children or young adults in large numbers, say--Kinch believes we wouldn't be able to produce vaccine fast enough to treat everyone, even if the vaccine was effective." (p. 334) Of course, any medical cure is far from a sure thing. Bryson notes how while we are by far healthier globally on average due to the defeat of major infectious diseases--tuberculosis, pneumonia, and most influenzas--by a small set of treatments, more people now face health risks from lifestyle choices. Indeed, the average American life span suffers in comparison to the citizens of most modern advanced economies, despite spending far more per capita on health care than other nations. We're overstuffed (eating 20% more calories per day on average than citizens of healthier European countries, Bryson says), oversedentary due to desk jobs and television obsessions, and oversedated on medications that have marginal benefits or lead to prescription drug dependency. This is still the best time to be alive for every human in every country, and America is still a great country with great doctors and nurses, but pushing away from the pizza, putting down the remote, and considering improvements to the economic and political climate of health care could benefit every body.It's no sin to be glad you're alive in the body you've been given. Enjoy it with the curiosity and the attention it deserves courtesy of Bryson.
A delightful overview of the amazing, perplexing, gross, and downright bizarre things that make up our human body home. My first Bryson - have I been missing out?!

The Body by Bill BrysonI picked up this book because the cover intrigued me. That...and the title of course. "The Body - a guide for occupants" - now if that isn't a simple yet clever title guaranteed to increase readership, I don't know what is. Because all of us are, for this life atleast, trapped in the limited yet wonderful physical entity called The Body. So as long as we are occupying The Body, why not read a guide that will help us understand our bodies a little better? Life is nothing short of a miracle. And for human life to have evolved to the current form from having started off as single-celled organisms is pretty remarkable. The Body is composed of different organ systems working in symphony powered by this 'invisible' energy called Life. The author neatly delves into different parts of The Human Body - with dedicated chapters for the organ systems (like respiratory, nervous, circulatory, among others). You also get to hear interesting anecdotes on major and minor scientific discoveries and he also shines a light on some lesser known heroes and heroines in the scientific field who did not get due credit for their contributions. There are many moments in this book that will fill you with awe and wonder. They may just make you appreciate your bodies a little more as it quietly goes about its business day in day out keeping you alive and active. That is - until disease or illness strikes. There are chapters that discuss what happens when things go wrong (disease) and very wrong (cancer). The book ends on a sobering note with a reminder of the eternal truth - death. Because that is going to happen one day. It is the journey between birth and death that our bodies help us traverse..and it's important to keep it primed up with good food, regular exercise and restful sleep.

In the same vein as "A Short History of Nearly Everything", Bryson tackles his next ambitious subject, the human body. Once again, he does an excellent job of taking complex systems and ideas, and bringing them down to our level. I found this book truly fascinating,... and also a little gross at times. Some of the details he shared hit a little too close to home.Here is a sample of some things that I found really interesting: - The outer layer of your skin is almost entirely dead cells. So when you look at a person, what you are seeing is mostly cadaver. - When you sunburn, your skin turns red because your blood vessels are swelling up. That is also why you feel hot to the touch. - Your body produces 5-10 ounces of tears every day. That's almost a full can of soda. - If everyone in the world were as overweight as Americans, it would be the equivalent of adding 1 billion people to the planet. - Food stays in your body for about 55 hours if you are a grown man. It's about 72 hours if you are a grown woman. - Poop is primarily brown because of expired red blood cells. - Gravity affects us differently based on our mass. So, a child half your height only experiences 1/132nd of the force of gravity when falling. This is why kids seem so indestructible. Just like he did in "A Short History of Nearly Everything", Bryson doesn't hesitate to say how much we still don't know about the human body. For example, modern opinion is that man is the result of millions of years of trial and error, where our most useful characteristics were passed on through survival of the fittest. But this doesn't explain why we have eyebrows. As far as we can tell, they serve no real evolutionary purpose, but they are very useful for self-expression. Also, we are the only species who experiences emotional crying. No one has a really good evolutionary explanation for why we do this. Bryson repeated over and over, "the purpose of X is unknown", or "nobody knows why X happens". Several times he described an attribute of the human body and then said that it was "one of life's many imponderables". There is no denying that we know far more than we did 100 years ago, but I'm sure the same will be said of us 100 years from now. Of course, any book exploring the science of the human body is going to end by talking about death. I learned that heart disease is the number one cause of death in America and kills more people than cancer, influenza, pneumonia, and accidents combined. We hear so much about cancer and are often worried about getting it (rightly so), but in reality we should be worried about taking better care of our hearts. One in three Americans dies of heart disease. Bryson also shared this little nugget: the average body in a sealed coffin takes between 5 and 40 years to decompose. Lovely thought. Bryson ended the book with a great line. After talking about burial and cremation, he abruptly says "And that's you gone. But was fun while it lasted." It was just a funny way to end, and it fit perfectly with his quippy sense of humor. Excellent book, and highly recommended.

It is incredible how recently in history we've begun to figure out what is going on inside our incredibly complex human body. The lethal surgical procedures of yesteryear have been replaced by the unnecessary over-medications today. Even safe surgical procedures today need to be evaluated on an excel sheet for true life-quality gain vs cost vs percent effectiveness.Five pages from the end of the book, this statement captures what we 'know' quite well:Some people live longer than they out to by any known measures. Costa Ricans have only about one-fifth the personal wealth of Americans, and have poorer health care, but live longer. Moreover, people in one of the poorest regions of Costa Rica, the Nicoya Peninsula, live longest of all, even though they have much higher rates of obesity and hypertension. The also have longer telomeres. The theory is that they benefit from closer social bonds and family relationships. Curiously, it was found that if they live alone or don't see a child at least one a week, the telomere length advantage vanishes. It is an extraordinary fact that having good and loving relationships physically alters your DNA. Conversely, a 2010 study found, not having such relationships doubles your risk of dying from any cause.This book reminded me of We Have No Idea: A Guide to the Unknown Universe. Both books go into depths about the latest knowledge in their fields (Astrophysics, and the Human Body). We think these scientists know SO MUCH. But you come away from both books realizing that we are no where close to having these fields REALLY figured out. Every page of both books reveals great knowledge, yet abundant need for more research. Do you know we don't have 'wet' receptors? When you sit down on a wet bench, you can really get quite wet before your feel the TEMPERATURE difference. Too late!Babies born vaginally pick up microbes from the mother not gained in C-section. These are now being realized to be protective microorganisms. This can predispose you for certain diseases.The benefit of mother's milk is incredible. But the infant formula industry is worth $70 billion. So lets outlaw breast-feeding outside your home confines?This book came out prior to Covid. But the Diseases chapter speaks right to this topic."The fact is," he (Washington University's Michael Kinch) says, "we are really no better prepared for a bad outbreak today than we were when Spanish flu killed tens of millions of people a hundred years ago. The reason we haven't had another experience like that isn't because we have been especially vigilant. It's because we have been lucky."I listened to the Audio Book read by the author. He is a good reader. I bought a hard-copy too so I can highlight key points. The notes and full index in the appendix are handy to look items up.

Direct toen ik dit boek zag in mijn mail, wou ik het lezen. Met een bang hart want ik lees zelden tot nooit non-fictie. Met andere woorden, dit was een uitdaging voor mij.“Het lichaam, een reisgids” gaat simpelweg over het lichaam. Over alle aspecten ervan en zeer veel leuke weetjes. Wist je trouwens dat je 50 à 100 haren per dag verliest? En dat je je 30 tot 40 keer omdraait of van houding verandert in je slaap?Het was een zeer interessant boek, alles wat ik in mijn eerste jaar Ergotherapie gezien heb qua het lichaam, kwam hier aan bod en dit was een leuke opfrisser. Hoewel dit boek voor mij een jaar eerder er mocht zijn, de manier waarop alles wordt uitgelegd was zeer aangenaam. Dit zou me zeker geholpen hebben tijdens het studeren.Desondanks ik wat voorkennis had, is dit toch een toegankelijk boek om te lezen, ook al weet je niet veel over het lichaam. Ik geef toe, niet elke Latijnse term kende ik, maar het opzoeken ervan was ook niet zo hard nodig. De context legde het woord wel uit.Wat dit boek ook zo leuk maakt is de humor van Bryson. Alles wordt op een leuke manier uitgelegd en zijn humor dat af en toe boven komt, maakt dat ik toch wel genoten heb om dit te lezen.Het spijtige aan dit boek is dat het soms zijn focus verliest. Er zit bijvoorbeeld een hoofdstuk in over het evenwicht maar het gaat dan over koorts terwijl ik niet direct een verband tussen de twee zag, nog steeds niet eigenlijk. Het was fijner geweest als de focus van het hoofdstuk behouden werd, hierdoor had ik soms het gevoel dat de auteur van de hak op de tak wou springen.In de meeste hoofdstukken komen er ook pathologieën aan bod. Hier heb ik een opmerkelijk iets gevonden. Namelijk: het hoofd. In dit hoofdstuk werden de zintuigen besproken en werd er vermeld welke pathologie je kan hebben (natuurlijk niet allemaal) als je geur of zicht niet normaal werken. Dit vond ik zeer interessant, daar niet van, maar ik vind het enorm spijtig dat er bij het gehoord niets vermeld was over slechthorendheid of doofheid. Enkel dat als je trilharen vernietigd zijn, die niet terug groeien. Benoem het gewoon, het is niet erg hoor. Dit viel mij gewoon op. Maar goed, dit is een beetje te vergaand.Dit is mijn eerste non-fictie boek in jaren dat ik vrijwillig lees (lees: geen schoolboek) en heb er ontzettend van genoten. Het leest zeker trager dan een gewoon fictief boek, maar ik heb zeker veel geleerd van dit boek. Bryson is een goede auteur omdat hij alles zo luchtig maar tegelijk serieus kan brengen, met een gezonde portie humor. 4 van 5 sterren geef ik dit boek.En vergeet niet, je lichaam is en blijft een mysterie!Dit boek mocht ik lezen voor De club van echte lezers. Hiervoor dank dat ik een exemplaar mocht ontvangen van hen en Atlas Contact. Dit beïnvloedt mijn mening niet.

Interesting and informative and a very enjoyable read. Bryson brings the subject of the body to life with lots of sad and amazing stories of discoveries and the history of diseases and many other areas. There's also so many stories of people who either didn't get the credit they deserved or it was stolen from them. The part about pathologists risking their own lives to bring more understanding to diseases brought tears to my eyes. I already knew some of the areas covered but hey, what the hell, it's good to be reminded. Bryson is definitely a talented writer and he's brings the subject to life with so many details it's hard to take it all in. This is a book I will be reading again in the future.Read this book

Bill Bryson is one of the most widely read and beloved writers on so many subjects, be it travelogues to obscure locations, the history of the universe, and now the most ridiculous subject of them all, your body. Just kidding, not YOUR body, but the human body, and at all times Bryson is an erudite and irreverent guide through this endlessly fascinating subject, right up to the various ways the body expires.For me, the most interesting area discussed was the evolution of our knowledge of nutrition since those of us even just over the age of 30 can remember when nutritional and dietary suggestions were quite different than they are now. Bryson is an effective guide through a lot of the unscientific BS that pervades these discussions and offers an up to date account of proper amounts of exercise and nutritive consumption. He also details where some of these misconceptions may have come from, usually a misreading of a single study that was leaded to the popular media. Bryson is also quite clear where we still have no idea as to why certain things happen, or exist, or how to combat them and this forms at times the most distressing aspect of the work, though obviously necessary. The quick little asides and meanderings on how incredible some aspects of our regular functioning are, make for great reading especially in the chapter on all of the various chemicals your body uses and produces on a regular basis. As I mentioned, Bryson can be irreverent and waggish when discussing certain things and this pervades the chapter on sex. One clean but perfectly expressed point on why we may have evolved to engage in this practice instead of mere cloning by single-sex organisms occurs later in the work:"Sex may dilute our personal contribution to posterity, but it is great for the species. By mixing and matching genes, we get variety and that gives us safety and resilience. It makes it harder for diseases to sweep through whole populations. It also means that we can evolve. We can hold on to beneficial genes and discard ones that impede our collective happiness. Cloning gives you the same thing over and over. Sex gives you Einstein and Rembrandt - and a lot of dorks, too, of course."Those wanting a more academic appraisal of these areas along with an examination of our evolutionary history should definitely check out Harvard Professor Daniel Lieberman's, "The Story of the Human Body." Lieberman is someone, also, that Bryson references heavily throughout the work. However those looking for an up to date appraisal of the human body from a masterful storyteller should also consider this fantastic volume.

Still trying to get some walking in (early in the morning before many people are out) so I was able to chomp through the last chapters of this in a couple of days. Recommend if you like a good non-fiction deep dive, bonus if you're looking for a long audiobook.

Os livros que tinha lido de Bill Bryson até agora – Breve História de Quase Tudo e  Em Casa – foram duas leituras muito interessantes, em que aprendi imenso. Fiquei desde então com vontade de ler mais da sua obra e aproveitei este lançamento recente para satisfazer esse desejo. Desta vez, Bill Bryson propõe-se percorrer o corpo humano, por todas as suas diversas e variadas partes, e levar o leitor a conhecer mais sobre a forma como funcionamos e o verdadeiro milagre que é a nossa existência. O Corpo – Um Guia para Ocupantes é um livro para curiosos. Em cada capítulo, Bill Bryson ocupa-se de um dos nossos sistemas ou órgãos, fala um pouco sobre a história da evolução do conhecimento sobre o mesmo, enquanto vai apresentando exemplos e factos pouco conhecidos sobre o tema em causa. Isto faz com que a leitura nunca se torne enfadonha, apesar de alguns termos técnicos desconhecidos do comum dos mortais. O autor volta aqui a conseguir um excelente equilíbrio entre factos e a componente de entretenimento, de tal forma que chega a parecer que é simples fazê-lo.Li este livro antes de termos entrado todos em quarentena, mas quando a COVID-19 já era uma realidade bem presente. No 
Capítulo 20 – Quando as Coisas Correm Mal: Doenças
 , Bill Bryson fala sobre epidemias passadas e refere (pág. 397): “ Uma doença pode ou não tornar-se uma epidemia, e isso depende de quatro fatores: o quão letal é, a sua capacidade de encontrar novas vítimas, a facilidade ou dificuldade de a conter e a suscetibilidade a vacinas. […] Um vírus bem sucedido é aquele que não mata demasiado bem e consegue circular com um grande raio de alcance “. Mais à frente, falando sobre o ébola (pág. 398): “ Em várias ocasiões, graças a viagens aéreas, conseguiu escapar para outros países, mas felizmente foi contido em todos esses casos. É possível que não tenhamos sempre tanta sorte. […] É espantoso, na verdade, que não aconteçam coisas más com maior frequência. Segundo uma estimativa mencionada por Ed Yong no Atlantic, o número de vírus em aves e mamíferos com potencial para atravessar a barreira das espécies e infetar os humanos pode ser na ordem dos 800.000. É muito perigo potencial. “.Sinto-me sempre mais rica quando leio os livros deste autor, e esta leitura reforçou o quanto gosto de não ficção. Bill Bryson escreve livros informativos, que se lêem quase como ficção pela fluidez e humor que neles inclui, sem nunca descurar o seu verdadeiro objetivo que é aumentar o conhecimento do leitor sobre o que o rodeia – ou, neste caso, sobre o que tem dentro de si. Gostei muito e recomendo.

Does what it says on the tin. And reads exactly as you would expect from Bryson: well written, well researched, informative, revealing and entertaining. One factor that stood out for me was the sheer number of times that a scientific or medical theory took flight, was seized upon by the media, and stuck as a firmly believed fact despite subsequent research that proves the theory to have no scientific basis or 100% proven to be wrong. It's quite scary how much this happens. But because whole industries emerge to capitalise on what are ultimately urban legends, they are incredibly hard to quash. This book might as easily been titled Health, and there is unavoidable overlap in the subject matter, but it seemed the second half of the book was primarily focused on health and disease. And this is where a small but disappointing element here poked its head out. Although still a bit niche/controversial there's a steadily growing acceptance by medical professionals, that psychogenic disease is a grossly underestimated factor in our health, particularly in the area of chronic pain. The chapter on chronic pain was either disappointingly researched or deliberately ignored, despite evidence that would be hard to miss if investigating this area, so I suspect the latter. There were many points in the book, where the evidence was right there in his own words, yet he chose not to acknowledge it. There was even a chapter about Akureyri disease, which broke out in Iceland in the 1940s where no physical factors could be found and scientists concluded its genesis as psychogenic "which means" Bryson says "they had no idea whatsoever what caused it". It absolutely doesn't mean that Bill! It means it was psychogenic! I love Bryson but that is one of the most ignorant or deliberately obtuse lines I've ever read. A small factor overall. But it left a bad taste.To end on a better note, I actually wailed "Oh no" when I realised Bryson was narrating his own book. He does not have a good track record, whereas his regular narrator William Roberts does an amazing job of capturing the personality in his writing, an endeavour the author has failed to do in previous recordings. However, I think he's had some coaching, as he was a lot more engaging than past narrations.

Bryson had so much medical information to share in this book that there was almost no room for his signature wit! He managed to squeeze in just enough humorous turns of phrase that it was recognizable as Bryson. Man did I learn so much, reading whole passages aloud to my wife, an ER nurse, who would raise her eyebrows in surprise that the average person doesn't know what RH factor is, or what organ the appendix protrudes off of, or how miraculous insulin is. There were fewer supporting anecdotes than expected, but the facts and cases Bryson imparted were super "sticky" – they'll stay with me for a while. He knows exactly how long to write about a subject, in crystal clear and agreeable sentences, before moving on. A solid read."The body is often likened to a machine, but it is so much more than that. It works twenty-four hours a day for decades without (for the most part) needing regular servicing or the installation of spare parts, runs on water and a few organic compounds, is soft and rather lovely, is accommodatingly mobile and pliant, reproduces itself with enthusiasm, makes jokes, feels affection, appreciates a red sunset and a cooling breeze.... And how do we celebrate the glory of our existence? Well, for most of us by eating maximally and exercising minimally. Think of all the junk you throw down your throat and how much of your life is spent sprawled in a near-vegetative state in front of a glowing screen. Yet in some kind and miraculous way our bodies look after us, extract nutrients from the miscellaneous foodstuffs we push into our faces, and somehow hold us together, generally at a pretty high level, for decades. Suicide by lifestyle takes ages."

What an interesting book on a subject that could otherwise be so dry and complicated. Human biology, physiology and anatomy for the layman for which only Bill Bryson in his inimitable way could make this subject so readable. As someone in my mid-seventies having to visit doctors more frequently, it was time to learn why my body is causing issues and just how modern medicine could help, this was a must read book. The book is divided into 23 chapters dealing with different functions of the body. You could read by choosing any chapter or subject of interest. However, I recommend starting at least with the first three. Bryson says, "The brain is you. Everything else is plumbing and scaffolding". As he takes us on a tour of the body there are plenty of medical anecdotes, fun facts and interesting trivia. Plus, a plethora of diseases to think about. The author points out how medical science has evolved, the mistakes made in the past and how much we still don't know. Bryson often speaks of evolution to explain the many complex functions of the body and how we differ from other mammals, such as how we fell out of trees to become bipedal. That's ok, but others could likely see the marvelous laws of nature set up not by accident but by an intelligent creation, even over millions of years.The only other book I have read by this author is his popular and lighthearted, " A walk in the woods". Made into a delightful movie of the same title starring Robert Redford and Nick Nolte in 2015.

How can you not like this? It's another of Bryson's fact and trivia books, this time covering the body from top to toe - in a sense - and uncovering all manner of interesting information about how the body ticks, and about the people who made the discoveries. And how there's still a great deal we just don't know about the body, even though you'd think we were up with the play completely by now. As always the anecdotal material is fascinating: the scientists who literally killed themselves in various ways to make discoveries - or unwittingly killed themselves while making discoveries. The scientists who didn't discover something new but claimed they did, and caused the real discoverer to be cast in the background. The scientists who did all manner of appalling things to themselves and others in order to learn about how our bodies work, and the men and women who healed others by trying something different instead of something that killed as many as it cured. It can be almost overwhelming, but you read on, because after all, who isn't interested in their own body and what's going on inside it?

Auf den ersten Seiten (bis etwa 15%-20%) hatte ich wirklich keinen Spass mit diesem Buch. Ich dachte sogar daran abzubrechen, weil ich einfach nicht noch mehr zahlen hören/lesen wollte. Zahlen die man sich nicht merken kann und die unablässig auf mich eingeprasselt sind… und dabei hatte ich mich so auf das Buch gefreut. Dann plötzlich stellte ich fest, wie viel von dem was Bryson sagte in meinem Kopf hängen geblieben ist. Nach und nach kamen mir diese kleinen Geschichten und Fakten wieder in den Sinn. Und das Buch fing echt an mir Spass zu machen.Bryson gibt hier einen echten, umfangreichen und spannenden Überblick über den ganzen Körper, vom Scheitel bis zur Sohle. So viele Dinge die ich noch nicht wusste und so viele Dinge, die die Medizin noch gar nicht weiss! 😲 Für jeden der gerne den Klugscheisser auf einer Party markiert, ist das Buch genau richtig! Ich habe eine gute Allgemeinbildung, freue mich aber immer etwas Neues dazu zu lernen und dafür ist dieses Buch grandios, auch wenn man die Zahlen nur am Rande mitbekommt und diese auch kaum speichert: Eine absolute Empfehlung, auch für „Nicht-Medizin-Studenten“… 😉😁👍🏻

cw: mentions of suicideI think this might be my last Bill Bryson book. In the past, I’ve found them entertaining if lacking depth and being a bit insensitive, the last of which I attributed to decades since publication. After reading this book, I must revise my opinion on this last point.This book was published in 2019. A scientist shouldn’t be described as “exotic” because they hold multiple nationalities. The subtle undertones upholding male superiority are not appreciated, not to mention the blatant anti-transgender language in the chromosome section. The sharp language of describing those who die by suicide as “killing themselves” and the multiple suicide tips are extremely damaging and frankly unnecessary. If all of this isn’t enough, the writing is straight up lazy - he copy pasted the same sentence into multiple chapters, and I even recognized some sentences from previous books. Perhaps I’m being sensitive, but it took away from the actual content for me. The book is well-researched, but nothing else about it sits comfortably with me.
Such a great reading! I thoroughly enjoyed it, indeed.Very recommended as short history of the most prominent parts of medicine.

Terrific Read !! Simple, easy and entertaining. Reading this book was really like reading a novel. I liked author style, he got a way with words and good sense of humor. The book is divided into 21 chapters. Starting with building humans 🧬 and ending with death 💀. In between, author tackles one of the body system in each chapter, related topics to the body (sleep, pain) and diseases. The most interesting thing about this book is that he’s linking every system or part of the body with the history of medicine, history of diseases and fascinating stories about scientists and their discoveries.As the book is popular science, it is definitely not written for medical professionals or academics. It’s not that shallow nor that deep, both professionals and laypersons could enjoy such a read. The content Seems more like basic knowledge and good for students i would recommend +11 to read. You can also check out this documentary on Netflix: “HUMAN: THE WORLS WITHIN”. Same content as the book(more or less).

Bryson is always intelligent, quirky, and entertaining and The Body is all of that. He takes often dry factual material and enlivens it. The organization of the book, by body sections and systems, is clear. His interjection of strange stories about the personalities and lives of some significant medical researchers adds to the fun.The very last chapters are somewhat different. Instead of describing physiological facts, he begins talking about the health care systems in different countries. He compares death rates, death causes, number of tests run, and of course, cost. Some might find this off-putting but it seemed to me to be germane when talking about the body. He ends naturally enough by talking about dying and again discusses different death experiences according to various factors. All in all, a book that informs but holds your attention and encourages pondering. Thanks to the publisher and to Net Galley for providing me with an ARC in exchange for my honest review.

This is another highly entertaining book by Bill Bryson. I'll happily read anything he ever writes on any subject whatsoever. In The Body he takes on the wonderful and complex thing that is the human body he makes it comprehensible to the reader. He does this with humor and an eye for fascinating details. Along the way he tells the stories of the scientific heroes who have made important discoveries about how the human body works, and he gives them the praise (and occasional censure) that they deserve. Bryson simply does not know how to be boring and this book is enjoyable from beginning to end. I, on the other hand, DO know how to be boring, and I've been boring my family with facts about the human body for the past few days. They are going to be relieved that I'm finally done with this book.

This is one of the most interesting and fascinating books I have ever read. It is also at times horrifying, especially when the chapters talk about research, pharmaceuticals and medical tests. I wasn't going to read it when I first heard of it because I thought it would be too "scientific" and hard to read. Having read most all of Bill Bryson's books, I should have known better. It is easy to understand and sprinkled with his own brand of laugh out loud funny asides. The amount of research that goes into any excellent non-fiction book is always amazing to me. Besides Bryson, I enjoy any non-fiction by Erik Larson, Simon Winchester and David McCullough. If you like to learn while reading an enjoyable "story", I high recommend all these authors. That said, Bill Bryon's "The Body" is one of the very best!

this is a lazy history of the human body, but fantastically written. it is not meant to be a medical textbook, but i do think i’ve recalled more trivia + interesting facts from reading this book than my undergrad degree in medical science. i am not saying that everything is explained well enough to enable you to start diagnosing weird maladies on hapless patients, but it's enough to get you interested in the odd, fleshy body of yours. what i loved most about this volume is that bill bryson has paid particular attention to the unsung heroes of medical science, practice, and discovery - the ones who were ignored and ridiculed by the rest of their professional colleagues for their outrageous discoveries, and the lab assistants who put in the hard yards but came last in the acknowledgements of discovery.

This book humbled me very much. Please read it. We all are capable of some degree of ingratitude for the complicatedness that we embody, literally, within us.The smallest bones in your body can be found in your ears, and they're so tiny that can be quite easily be placed on a shirt button. A functioning human heart when plucked out and severed can gush out blood that would spray for 3 meters in distance. Our part of the eyes that the world gets to see is the only 1/6th of the whole thing. That's eerily mighty. The book is generously peppered with trivia like these.But also some humbling trivia too. Your body when cremated results in ashes that weigh around 2 kilograms. That's how inconsequential we are, yet we embody something incomprehensibly stunning too. My highest possible recommendation.

So seriously fascinating! Honestly, I was not bored once during 13 hours of listening to this audiobook. This is the first book I've read by Bill Bryson and it won't be the last! He does an amazing job and providing a lot of information in a clear and interesting way. One warning though....there are parts, that while super interesting, are also uncomfortable to listen to. It contains frightening info about antibiotics resistance, gruesome historical medical treatments and cringeworthy ways people have died or failed to die when it seems like they should have. Also, take a walk and eat a vegetable. It is amazing how much your body depends on you moving around a little and eating reasonably.

DNF. I can't believe I'm DNF-ing a Bill Bryson book, but that's how it is. I was so looking forward to reading this one, as I read and loved all of Bryson's books up till now. However, this one doesn't feel like a Bill Bryson book at all. It's very dry, there's none of Bryson's wonderful humor in it, as there was in his "History of Everything," a superb scientific read. There are some sort of nasty, or at least snarky comments here and there, and as others here have mentioned, unbased conclusions which seem to be based on the author's views. I identify with his views, but would like my popular science books to prove things to me based on scientific knowledge and not opinion. Not sure what happened here but I don't have to continue reading this.

One of the most interesting books I have read in a long time.I have always been interested in anatomy and the biology of living organisms, especially the human one. I remember taking a human biology course in my very first semester in college about 45 years ago and just being blown away by how fascinating everything was. The professor certainly had a lot to do with it – it was obvious to everyone that he just loved the subject he was teaching.Bill Bryson brings that same enthusiasm to this book. I can tell that he is fascinated by exactly the same things that fascinate me – and he writes about them superbly. The book is mostly just a non-stop list of factoids told with a lot of historical context. Some people may not appreciate it as much as I do. But for me it was great reading.

"The day when people once again die from the scratch of a rose thorn may not be far away."I loved this book. Full of easily digestible scientific facts, historic stories, and unexpected connections that all relate to our bodies. It is entertaining to read while being quite educational and even mesmerizing at times. I would even recommend this read to a doctor, not just a lay person, particularly specialists that don't always look at the whole body in the diagnosis and treatment of disease... a lot of good reminders what and where to look. Fascinating for any age or profession/educational background.

A well compiled and written book of facts about the human body, accesible and entertaining (as well as horrifying in some instances) A book that I appropriatly read near halloween due to some of it's morbidity, but there is also a great deal of light heartedness and Bill is a good guide with his dryness.The parts of it are well put togethor in well thought out way, displaying the most interesting and important facts without going on too long.I learnt a lot of interesting facts as well as some grisly tales to spook some of my friends if such an appropriate time comes along, along with humorous tales of discovery and facinating things, of course.

This book is what you’d expect. Pleasant and entertaining writing from Bryson, but obviously too broad to be at all insightful. My main gripe, and I can’t remember if I noticed this before in his other books, is that at least half the content is historical gossip about the people who discovered things. Even then there’s just not enough time to do them justice, and Bryson comes off as ignorantly judgmental at best (“so and so discovered XYZ but he was a philanderer” etc. - so what?). Learned a some interesting facts (which I’ll likely forget within the next few weeks), and it’s not awful, but I can’t really recommend it.

Πολύ ευχάριστο βιβλίο με άπειρες χρήσιμες πληροφορίες για το ανθρώπινο σώμα και την ιατρική επιστήμη. Αυτό που μου έκανε πρόσθετη εντύπωση είναι το πλήθος ιστορικών στοιχείων και περιστατικών που αναφέρει ο συγγραφέας, εστιάζοντας στα πρόσωπα που διαδραμάτισαν καταλυτικό ρόλο στις διάφορες ιατρικές ανακαλύψεις, αλλά και στις ανθρώπινες ιστορίες που κρύβονται πίσω από αυτά. Ίσως θα μπορούσε να έλεγε δυο λογάκια παραπάνω για τις δυνατότητες που ανοίγονται με τις τρέχουσες τεχνολογικές ανακαλύψεις και για τις προβλέψεις των επιστημόνων όσον αφορά το που μπορούν να οδηγήσουν αυτές οι ανακαλύψεις. Όπως και να έχει διαβάστε το. Είναι εύκολο και σε πολλά σημεία διασκεδαστικό.

Very interesting read but the stories are too Americentric. Since I'm Polish it came to my attention that the author mentioned Marie Skłodowska Curie in only one short sentence (even though she died from exposure to radiation - it begs to be mentioned in that given context), and didn't even say a word about Leśniowski while talking about Crohn's (he was the first person to describe this disease). Makes me wonder how many interesting scientists, doctors etc. from different countries were also omitted (purposefully or not, it's hard to tell).

Much like his previous book, "A Short History of Nearly Everything", "The Body" offers a brief and entertaining tour to the human body. If you are an avid science reader, a lot of the information provided here are probably not new to you and some can seem a little too superficial. Still, I think this book would be a great starter for anyone who's curious about the human anatomy and biology. (Aliens out there, take note!)

Another entertaining and informative masterpiece from Bill Bryson. It's always fun listening to the author read his works. I learned so much new information about "the body" and even the stuff I had heard before was presented with a fresh outlook. Bryson is a true wordsmith and his delivery is always interesting and witty. But the author tackles difficult topics such as medical 'advances,' historical and modern medicine and he has an amazing command of his subject.

I am so grateful to Doubleday books for the eARC of Bill Bryson’s The Body. This book embodies all of my favorite kinds of science writing - it takes a topic we are all familiar with, our bodies, and then lets the reader see their own body in a new way. I am constantly on the lookout for books to share with my anatomy students, and this has catapulted to the top of my stack! It is wonderfully thorough, but Bryson’s wit & writing style make it easy to digest.

This was a great read. Definitely a high-level flyover of a ton of information. I appreciated his honesty about how hard it is to draw conclusions about food and disease, as well as his explanation of what it actually means to increase your chances of disease—unexpected in a popular-level book like this. My one complaint is that, contrary to my usual feelings, i wish the author had not read the audio version.

Not as many caveats re: research methodologies and current scientific blindspots, but still a lovely book. It is comforting to get information about a sweep of anatomical, psychological, and sociological subjects, especially as an occupant of a human body. Pretend you're a curious 14-year-old again and listen up: you might appreciate your own dwelling a little more in the process of sating curiosity.

Lovingly presented with humour and kindness and great attention to detail. Even the scariest part of the book about all the things that can go wrong in a body left me with a sense of optimism, and I thoroughly enjoyed every bit - even (and especially) the bonus about the sense of hearing that comes with the audible version.

Just another amazing book by Bryson. Other than scientists and science lovers, its hard to imagine that anybody can understand (let alone enjoy) a science book. The writer takes you skillfully into an amazing journey inside our bodies and explaining not only the mechanism of our organs, but also the their history (naming, false believes, new discoveries..etc.).A useful and joyful read.

Bryson does another remarkable job of packaging information and making it both informative and entertaining. This is a ggreat addition to his growing body of work on history, science and anthropology. His style is light, without being frivolous. His facts are supportive without being boring, and each chapter seems to be as Goldilocks might have said- not too long, not too short, just right.

As always, Bryson’s writing is easily read as he hops from one anecdote to another, reintroducing us to the sense of awe for inhabiting our incredible bodies. Abundant with wit, humility, origins, comparable sizes (which parts of you could be wrapped around the planet and which are the size of a greyhound bus), karmic irony and - of course - etymology.

(audio version) Bryson at his very best. A measured, well paced journey through what we know (and just as interestingly what we don't know) about the human body. Educational, entertaining, sometimes frightening, funny - doffing his cap to a number of unsung heroes of the medical world.I would recommend this book (certainly the audio version) to anyone.

I always enjoy a good Bill Bryson book. This novel is a brief overview of just about everything having to do with your body and how it functions. I don't agree with Mr. Bryson about the origins of man, but I found the book informative without being tedious. And of course, it includes some of Mr. Bryson's dry humor to keep things fun.

The human body is SO badass. This book gave me a renewed appreciation for my body, and quite frankly a stronger desire to treat it better. A lot of cool facts in this book - things that I didn't know or simply forgot about. It's a digestible (pun intended?) way to look at how incredible our bodies are & the science/medical advancements that have been made over time.

Got this free on my Kindle app. Figured it's Bill Bryson so it must be good. Eh. While his writing style is as entertaining as usual, the topic of the book is basically summarizing Wikipedia articles about various body parts and functions. I skipped around and read the few chapters I was interested in. Not worth the time to read all 450 pages of this book even if it is entertainingly written.

A great overview of the human body by the witty Bill Bryson. Medical history/human anatomy books can sometimes be a bit much but Bryson keeps it just in-depth enough to stay interesting to the layperson.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for the ARC!

This book was okay. It was definitely a good balance of being accessible, but also detailed. I’d say this book was almost more of a history of the study of the body than an overview of information about the body. I enjoyed it, but didn’t find myself consumed by it.

The Body was one of the most fascinating books I’ve ever read. The author is able to take a subject that should be about as exciting as a text book, but inserts humor and unique stories that keep you hooked.

Bill Bryson is one of my favorite writers. I find his topics interesting and written with a dash of humor. Unfortunately, although I learned about the human body, I didn’t enjoy the book. I felt it was too long and couldn’t wait to finish it, which I did.
Interesting compendium of current research about the human body, its functions and diseases. Not comprehensive or encyclopedic but all the material is very interesting and even entertaining.
I detest all things medical and I am very squeamish, set that aside and it's still five stars! My mouth dropped open many times in shock and amazement, this is a terrific manual for all ages!
This was definitely a fascinating read. If Health class would have been this interesting, I would have actually paid attention. I learned some interesting things that I was not aware of.
4 1/2 stars
An interesting yet completely terrifying book... as if I needed to know all of the ways that I could die!
Book club — Katie’s pick! I greatly enjoyed this book and learned a ton. Might write more of a review later, but am too lazy rn.
Consistently interesting but not as gob-smackingly amazing as his other books.
An interesting and accessible journey through the human body. Byrson covers lots of fascinating information and research written in a way that makes it easy to understand.
Excelente! Muy entretenido y se aprende tanto. Me encantó de mis favoritos del año.
It took me a long time to finish this. I listened to it whike I worked but I couldn’t stand listening to Bryson read it. 🤭

That is a lot of potential danger.”“Women are anatomically different in one other very significant way: they are the sacred keepers of human mitochondria—the vital little powerhouses of our cells. Sperm pass on none of their mitochondria during conception, so all mitochondrial information is transferred from generation to generation through mothers alone. Such a system means that there will be many extinctions along the way. A woman endows all her children with her mitochondria, but only her daughters have the mechanism to pass it onward to future generations. So if a woman has only sons or no children at all—and that happens quite often, of course—her personal mitochondrial line will die with her. All her descendants will still have mitochondria, but it will come from other mothers on other genetic lines. In consequence, the human mitochondrial pool shrinks a little with every generation because of these localized extinctions. Over time, the mitochondrial pool for humans has shrunk so much that, almost unbelievably but rather wonderfully, we are all now descended from a single mitochondrial ancestor—a woman who lived in Africa about 200,000 years ago.
