Packed with information, Bill Bryson's agglomeration of medical discoveries, know-how and historic anecdotes in "The Body" absolutely matches his award-winning book "A Short History of Nearly Everything". Both are among the best non-fiction on human history. Knowing where we came from and what unimaginable sh*t we did in earlier times is such important knowledge to appreciate how far we came and how good we have it, both materially as medically. And to not go back with ideas like "curing cancer with urine therapy". Yes, those and similar spiritual practices still exist ... negating all building blocks and trial & error we went through during millenia, continuing the path of ignorance and human suffering. Both books could be made mandatory during public education.Some sh*t we did in our past:- Hygiene: Not washing your hands before a new surgery, bringing in bacteria from previous patients you treated. This was one of the main causes of death on the surgery table, for a long, long time. Doctors wearing dirty and blooded robes was a sign of "experience". The bloodier, the better. In 1900, +50% of the causes of death was by infection. Today it's 3%.- Trepanation: Primitive surgical attempts involving drilling holes into the skull, based on the flawed notion that it would release evil spirits or relieve intracranial pressure.- Bloodletting when ill "to air out the blood". Making you actually less able fight the disease. Some people went up to remove 50-75% of the blood from their body.- Blood transfusions: Early attempts at transfusions without proper blood typing and cross-matching, leading to fatal reactions and complications. We also tried blood transfusions from sheep, horses, cows, ... and even direct replacement with water and wine amongst others. Today we're sticking with blood transfusions from humans and that have a similar blood type.- Smallpox inoculation: Initial trials involving the direct application of scabs from infected individuals, which carried a risk of severe infection and disease transmission.- Horrible surgical techniques: Early crude methods of surgery, often resulting in high mortality rates due to infection and lack of anesthesia.- Anesthesia experimentation: Dangerous and unrefined exploration of substances like chloroform and ether for pain relief during surgeries. Today these are used in very specific doses. But it certainly was not always like that.- Organ transplantation: Initial failures and rejection issues due to limited knowledge of immunosuppression and tissue matching.- Electric shock therapy: Uncontrolled and excessive use of electric shocks for mental health treatment, lacking precision and adequate understanding of brain function.- Cancer treatments: Initial crude approaches to chemotherapy and radiation therapy, resulting in severe side effects and limited efficacy.- Brain lobotomy: Initial raw practices to remove brain parts to cure mental health conditions, like depression, shizophrenia, anxiety disorders and even being gay. The procedure was done with an ice pick through your eye, damaging connections in the prefrontal cortex of the brain. Sometimes leaving half of the ice pick behind. Generally lobotomy procedures had significant and irreversible side effects, including personality changes, cognitive impairment, and a general dampening of emotional responsiveness. Most people went to the crazy house. Rather few records were kept on the (non-)effectiveness and most of the surgeries were doing purely random damage. Over time, the use of lobotomy declined as alternative treatments as medications became available.- Etc. Etc. Etc. ...

Bill Bryson started out writing travel books. Not travel guides, but travelogues - notes on his thoughts as he traveled around, interesting anecdotes, fun random facts about a place. These remain my favorite Bryson books, but I've very much appreciated the turn he's taken in the last couple decades to write "travel books" that aren't geographic. A tour through all science in A Short History of Nearly Everything, or through the English language in The Mother Tongue: English and How It Got That Way, or several other topics. And now, the human body.First, a warning to those who are squeamish: it's the human body. All of it. In all its glory, grossness, and all the ways it can go wrong. And the weird and sometimes horrific ways we figured out how it worked. Bryson doesn't linger on the grossness, though there are a handful of anecdotes he appears to take a little more delight in recounting than I really enjoyed.It's overall a good book, though not a great one. It reminds me of the kind of "scientific" literature produced in late Roman and early medieval times, by people like Pliny the Elder and Isidore of Seville. A lot of facts, many things intended to pique the reader's interest, but overall superficial and something that would amuse as much as inform.But the benefit of living today, as opposed to in Isidore's day, is that if my curiosity is piqued by something in the book, I can deep dive into the vast amount of more technical literature out there waiting for me.The only thing that really annoys me about the book is that, because Bryson's not an expert in any of this, it's easy for him to say something silly and not catch the error. He's relying on real experts, reading lots himself and interviewing many of the brightest minds in these fields, but some stuff slips through the cracks. He gets particularly bogged down in this idea that “photons of light have no color” (p. 55), which makes literally no sense. He appears to have waded into some philosophical argument that color is epiphenomenal and occurs only in the mind, which is a controversial (and in a physicist's perspective, stupid) argument - but Bryson doesn't appreciate any of the physics or philosophy here, or that it could even be debatable, because he's basing everything on one so-called authority on the topic. On page 127, he explains that blood is red, but appears blue because of "a quirk of optics" where "a higher proportion of the red spectrum is absorbed, but more blue light is bounced back", which is literally the definition of something being blue. This very same thing comes up later with another sense, when he notes "none of those flavors or aromas actually exist. All that is really going on in your mouth is texture and chemicals" (p. 107). As if somehow something that's "just" chemicals isn't real? All that's going on in your brain is chemicals!I latch onto these points because it shows the danger of following a non-expert on an intellectual voyage. Like a good but non-expert guide through the wilderness, he can follow the map - but if the map's wrong, he won't know. But overall the book seems good, and you can't deny that Bryson is an entertaining author. I was thinking of giving the book three stars, but... even one of Bryson's less compelling works is better than what most authors could put together.
